PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is a need for an Independent and Multi-cultural Broadcasting Corporation to give a firm legislative and financial basis for the SBS Network.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should
Pass Senator Vigor's Bill with all expediency
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Haines (from 119 citizens) and Vigor (from 113 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned concerned citizens of Australia shows that:
the Joint Space Defence Research Facility at Pine Gap is a vital part of United States plans to fight a nuclear war, thus implicating Australia in these immoral plans;
spy satellites such as those linked to Pine Gap are used to spy on both allied and non-allied countries, including Australia;
these activities of Pine Gap are a destabilising influence in a dangerously uneasy world, raising the level of fear and distrust between nations;
the significance of Pine Gap to the United States of America is such that it is a prime nuclear target;
Pine Gap desecrates an Aboriginal dreaming track.

Your petitioners therefore strongly urge that the Australian Government give to the government of the United States of America the one year's notice required to terminate the lease on the Joint Space Defence Research Facility at Pine Gap.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support `The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of widespread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Mining Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the welfare of many employees and their families depends upon a healthy, expanding gold mining industry;
(ii) the success of many small businesses in gold mining towns also depends upon the continued profitability of gold mining and prospecting operations;

(iii) the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining and prospecting represents a threat to the profitability of these industries and will therefore cause widespread unemployment and depression throughout the whole gold mining industry.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Government to reject any proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining or prospecting thereby ensuring that the spectacular growth of the industry over recent years is continued.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the fringe benefits tax will place enormous cost increases on employers throughout Australia;
(ii) in so doing, the fringe benefits tax will raise the cost of employing labour, particularly in remote locations and it will inevitably worsen the already high level of unemployment in Australia;
(iii) much of the cost of the tax will be carried by employees as employers reduce benefits; and
(iv) the cost of the tax will harm small business particularly as these businesses will be unable to pass on the cost of the tax and as a result many may be forced to close.
Your petitioners therefore call upon the Government to repeal this unfair tax before it damages Australian business and thereby reduces the standard of living of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Whereas the fringe benefits tax will place a costly and unfair burden on independent schools.

The fringe benefits tax will have the most damaging impact upon schools which provide boarding accommodation for children as they are also required to provide accommodation for staff members to live in and supervise the boarders. Independent schools have limited resources and this additional impost will ultimately have to be passed on to parents, many of whom are already heavily committed to the financing of their children's education.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Parliament to recognise that the future of Australia depends upon the education given to its children and to exempt schools from the operation of the fringe benefits tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Country Hour
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

that any decision by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to reduce the local content of the programme, the `Country Hour', would represent yet another severe blow to Western Australian rural people;
that even under current programming Western Australian country people receive little locally produced radio, and

in view of the inefficiencies in the operations of the ABC disclosed by the Auditor-General, your petitioners call upon the Government to improve the efficient operation of the ABC before it reduces the local content of important rural programs such as the `Country Hour'.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Whereas the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985:
(i) does not include many of the rights which are fundamental to Australian society such as the right to own property and the right not to join a trade union;

(ii) by virtue of the extremely wide powers which it will give to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission, will take away many of our traditional rights such as the right to legal representation, the right to be confronted by one's accuser and the right to be heard in public; and
(iii) will therefore change many of the basic aspects of Australian life without people being given the opportunity to decide the Bill's fate at a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will reject the Bill of Rights in its present or any future form.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOUTH PACIFIC NUCLEAR FREE ZONE TREATY BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION (SEA DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 December, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Sanders for Senator Haines) proposed:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Haines moving the following motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate: That the Order of the Day relating to the consideration of the Customs Amendment (Prohibition of the Exportation of Uranium to France) Bill 1986 be called on immediately after consideration of the Order of the Day relating to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--
—This is a suspension motion, Senator Evans.
—Nonetheless, we can debate it?
—Yes.

—I have not had any notice of this matter from the Australian Democrats. I do not think it is a motion that can reasonably be supported. It is the desire, as I am well aware, of the Democrats to ensure that their motion about uranium sales to France gets an airing in this chamber. They will have an opportunity to do that in an amendment, which is in order, to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill which is before the Parliament now and which will be dealt with in the Committee stage quite soon, I hope. Under those circumstances, I do not think there is any justification-in terms of ensuring the Democrats the right, which they no doubt want to exercise, to have their particular point of view expressed-for taking procedures the extra stage and bringing on Senator Sanders's Bill. No doubt if his amendment to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill is passed in the Committee stage a question will arise at some appropriate stage as to when his Bill ought to be debated, but that question is wholly hypothetical at this stage.
—So you are saying in advance that you are not going to support the amendment; so there is no need to discuss our Bill.
—That question can be determined at the appropriate time. No rights will be put at risk by Senator Sanders's Bill not proceeding at this particular stage.

—The Opposition is entirely opposed to the motion that has been moved by Senator Sanders at this stage. The Senate is debating the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill. The Government wishes to implement that Treaty into legislation. We are in the middle of that debate. It is a most important debate. The Democrats propose to move amendments in the Committee stage which will raise this particular issue. There is absolutely no justification whatsoever in bringing forward a Bill which Senator Sanders gave notice of some time ago but which is not able to be debated at this stage of the session. This applies just as much to the Opposition as it does to the Democrats because Government business is now taking precedence over private members' business. This is a patent attempt by Senator Sanders and the Democrats to get around a rule which they have adopted-we have all adopted-for the sake of completing this session with reasonable expedition. For those reasons, the Opposition will support the Government in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The reason I brought the Customs Amendment (Prohibition of the Exportation of Uranium to France) Bill up at this time is that it should have been debated in cognate form with the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill because the amendments which I am going to move are part of that Bill. This was a mechanism to bring this Bill up. DEBATE.TITLE: SOUTH PACIFIC NUCLEAR FREE ZONE TREATY BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill 1986 and the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill 1986. Last night in the few moments I had available to me I made two observations. Firstly, the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty might be described as a Clayton's treaty. At least eight of the essential ingredients which would make up any substantial nuclear free zone treaty are not contained in the Treaty. Secondly, this is the one issue on which the people of Western Australia elected Senator Vallentine to represent them. Like the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, which I described as a Clayton's treaty, one might describe Senator Vallentine as a Claytons senator for nuclear disarmament: She is the senator one has when one does not have a senator.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the Treaty, what is of material consequence for Australia's defence and security and the security of the South Pacific region generally is the way the Treaty and the legislation impinge upon our allies, particularly on the United States of America, and specifically upon the integrity of ANZUS. One cannot but be struck by the words of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, who told us in his second reading speech: `The Treaty has been welcomed by the international community'. I do not know how Mr Hayden is able to draw that conclusion but if he is reflecting the views of the Eastern bloc countries, as distinct from those of the allies, I can quite understand where he has been looking for his congratulations.

Two things ought to be remembered about the Soviet position. First, the Soviet Union does not now have any naval presence in the South Pacific which is deployed in the defined zone. The Treaty will not, therefore, interfere with, affect or inhibit the activities of the Soviets while, at the same time, potentially restricting and retarding America's deployment within the zone. It ought, however, to be clearly recognised and understood that in the areas which abut or adjoin the zone, such as the Indian Ocean, the South East Asian region generally and the north Pacific region particularly, the Soviet presence and strength are growing at an alarming rate. Thirty-five per cent of the Soviet fleet is now to be found in the north Pacific. This is the largest of the Soviets' four fleets. It comprises over 800 ships and submarines. In the north Pacific is the Soviet Union's largest naval base outside the Warsaw Pact, Cam Ranh Bay, one of the spoils of the Vietnam War. This enormous sea power, with the major logistical back-up capacity of Cam Ranh Bay, provides the Soviet Union with a tremendous potential to penetrate the southern and western Pacific.

It is not without consequence that the Russian Pacific fleet, in the primary location of Cam Ranh Bay, is in no way inhibited, retarded or restricted by the provisions of the Treaty and it has enormous potential to penetrate south into what is loosely described as the nuclear free zone. Of course, apologists for the Soviets will respond with the comment that the Americans have the benefit of Subic Bay and the Clark air force base in the Philippines. However, as our shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Peacock, has said on a number of occasions, we ought not to be in the business of seeking parity or equality of strength, capacity or capability either within our region or within our immediate environment. It seems to me to be an obscene proposition that because the Americans have a base within the general geographic region, the Russians are also entitled to have one. That parity is reasonable and therefore we ought not to be complaining is a bizarre proposition. We ought to be concerned essentially about peace, our security and our defence. That can best be achieved by the strength of the presence of the United States within the region. One can hardly imagine our security being enhanced by reducing the capacity or the capability of our allies within the region.

This Treaty's net effect would effectively be to enhance the Soviets' capacity for parity within the South Pacific region while in no way placing restrictions upon their strength or capabilities. Of course the net losers in the South Pacific nuclear free zone will be the Australians and their allies. The very integrity, the very effectiveness of the ANZUS alliance is under threat by virtue of the provisions of this Treaty. The Government must concede that when the enabling legislation is in place and is complete, this Treaty can and will, under certain circumstances, override the ANZUS alliance. Its very provisions are ultra vires the provisions of the ANZUS Treaty. By any measure ANZUS and Australia's substitute bilateral agreements which we might make in the future with the United States are the cornerstone of our security, as they have been for the last 30 years, since the inception of ANZUS. I remind the Senate of the words of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, before the last Federal election, when he said of the ANZUS alliance:
. . . is now a more constructive relationship than it has ever been in peacetime . . . We have made ANZUS more than it has ever been, a close, genuine partnership.
I remind the Senate also of Mr Hawke's 1983 election policy speech, when he said:
We will maintain Australia's commitment to the ANZUS Treaty. Australia should never forget that the American alliance was forged by an Australian Labor Government, the Curtin Government.
Such is the pride that the Labor Party has in the ANZUS Treaty. Mr Hayden, as far back as 15 September 1983, had this to say after putting the Treaty under the microscope:

The review has led us to a firm and unequivocal reaffirmation of the alliance as fundamental to Australia's national security and foreign defence policies . . . Although the Treaty was drawn up a generation ago and in very different circumstances . . . the commitments and obligations that were accepted then, remain as valid and appropriate today.

So to this extent at least the Government represents the views of the Labor Party. One could now, of course, question that in many respects. Both sides of politics recognise the fundamental importance of ANZUS to our very security. Notwithstanding that recognition, this Government is prepared to compromise that security for the sake of the legislation presently before us, which both overrides and restricts ANZUS. Article 5 of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty and clauses 11 and 15 of the Bill forbid the permanent stationing of nuclear weapons within the zone. This may take the form of air, naval and army bases of nuclear armed forces, storage depots for nuclear weapons or seabed emplacements of nuclear weapons. I remind the Senate of the words used by the Department of Defence in its report in 1982 to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. These are the words of the Department of Defence, a non-politicised government department:

ANZUS also has a wide significance as an important part of the web of alliances and treaty arrangements which constitute the Western Alliance. It is within this framework that the Australian offer of home porting facilities at Cockburn Sound to the United States Navy ships engaged in patrolling the Indian Ocean, for example, is seen as linked to Australia's obligations under ANZUS.

The Australian Department of Defence has said that ANZUS is intrinsically linked to the providing of a capacity for home porting for American ships. Yet we now have legislation before us which consciously and wilfully is designed to ensure that there shall not be home porting within Australia's bases. The facts are that under certain circumstances and on occasions of a given threat ANZUS may well demand that a nuclear capacity force be stationed in the South Pacific, more particularly in Australia. It may well be that, as either a deterrence or a defence or both, under the ANZUS agreement Australia and/or the USA may wish to have such a capacity stationed on Australia's shores. Under this Treaty that option is closed. That part of ANZUS is no longer operative. That part of ANZUS is no longer able to be implemented. We now have legislation setting in concrete that the Americans are unable to fulfil all their obligations under the ANZUS Treaty. Frankly, we may well be witnessing stage 2 of the unravelling of ANZUS. I well remember what a prominent United States congressman had to say. I quote him, if I may:

Why should we sit back and allow ourselves to become Soviet targets . . . while others refuse to shoulder their responsibilities . . . we find our so-called friends and allies not even willing to have our aircraft land on their territory.

What have the Americans had to say in recent months about this Treaty, notwithstanding the fact that Mr Hayden has put it to us that it is well received in the international community? I quote from the National Times of April this year:

The United States Administration has bluntly told senior members of the Australian Government it believes Australia's initiative to establish a nuclear-free zone in the South Pacific will directly benefit the Soviet Union's global objectives.

At high-level talks in Canberra and Washington over the past two weeks, the US has taken an extremely hard line against the nuclear-free zone and has rejected Australian pressure for the United States to endorse it.
The US position led to a clash between US Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger and Australian Foreign Minister Bill Hayden in Canberra two weeks ago.

In his Canberra talks, Weinberger stated bluntly that the US believed the creation of the nuclear-free zone would `advantage the aggressor power' and disadvantage the US. He warned that Australia should not underestimate the Soviet Union's ambitions in the South Pacific.

Weinberger told the Australian ministers that if the US endorsed the South Pacific treaty there was a serious danger that similar zones would be established in other oceans and that the oceans of the world could become `linked by interlocking circles' of nuclear-free zones.
He made it clear the US saw the creation of the zone as a serious impediment to the free movement of US warships in the region.

So much for the welcoming by the international community of this wondrous zone that the Government has now cast upon the Australian community. The unravelling of ANZUS is quite naturally a dedicated pursuit of the Soviets. To quote Paul Dibb, the Government's adviser on defence matters:

The Soviet Union would like to see the ANZUS Alliance system disrupted in its favour and the close relationship that has been developed between Australia, New Zealand, and the United States with the ASEAN countries and with the nations of Oceania destroyed. The importance of ANZUS to the USSR needs to be clearly understood.

The Soviets are very conscious of the enormous influence the ANZUS alliance brings to the security of the South Pacific, not only by joint defence co-ordination, but also by the interchange of intelligence and by mutual co-operation. Anything which undermines this alliance quite naturally has the full support of the Soviets and hence their support for the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. Perhaps Mr Hayden was speaking of support for the treaty zone by the international community when he was referring to the congratulations he received from his Soviet counterpart at the United Nations in September 1985-surprise, surprise! This was followed in April 1986 by the Soviet Government stating that the South Pacific nuclear free zone proposal `met with a most positive response in the Soviet Union'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That makes it bad, does it?

—Clearly, it identifies the interests the Soviets have in removing ANZUS and destabilising the relationship of the components of ANZUS itself. The United States Department of Defense in its Soviet Military Power 1986 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Moscow has already sought to exploit the anti-nuclear sentiment in the Pacific Island states, Australia, and New Zealand through calls for nuclear-free zones that would have a much greater impact on US ships and aircraft than on those of the Soviets. This, coupled with their efforts to have states in this area deny access to the US could prove to be damaging to the Western strategic interests.
Of course, the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Forum delegates visited Moscow in February 1986. While the Soviets supported the Treaty they went on to say, and I quote the Soviet News Bulletin:

At the same time the Soviet side pointed out the importance of making certain that the agreement creating the nuclear-free zone really ensures the making of the territories of the signatory states into a zone completely free from nuclear weapons. This presupposes, in particular, a ban on the transit through the nuclear-free zone's territory of nuclear weapons and nuclear explosive devices, including visits at ports and air fields there by foreign warships and aircraft with nuclear weapons aboard.
We had our dear friend General Secretary Gorbachev stating:
The USSR supports proclaiming of the southern part of the Pacific as a nuclear free zone and urges all nuclear powers to guarantee its status in a unilateral or bilateral way.
That was reported by Tass in the Soviet News Bulletin on 29 July this year. It ought to be recognised that the Soviet support, in essence, is subject to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Therefore it is bad-is that what you are saying?

—Listen with care. No, I am not saying it is necessarily bad. In this case it is bad. Its motive is obvious. It ought to be recognised that the Soviet support is, in essence, subject to the same conditions as it imposed on the Latin American Treaty. I remind Senator Georges that the Soviet Union says that it supports the Treaty but I remind him of the qualification:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . authorizing the transit of nuclear weapons in any form would be contrary to the objectives of the treaty, and `incompatible with a non-nuclear status' of the zone; in cases where the treaty parties authorized actions incompatible with the zone's non-nuclear status, the Soviet Union reserved the right to reconsider its obligations under Protocol II.
What does Protocol II say? It states:
Each Party further undertakes not to use or threaten to use any nuclear explosive device against:
a) Parties to the Treaty; or
b) any territory within the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone for which a state has become a Party to Protocol I is internationally responsible.

The Soviets are saying that as long as the Treaty allows the navigation through the zone of warships with nuclear capability or nuclear power, they reserve the right to fire nuclear weapons into the zone. Their commitment is a Claytons commitment. They support the zone, provided that it abolishes bans and outlaws the home porting of American vessels. In the event that there is home porting of American vessels or vessels of any other of Australia's allies, they reserve the right to take all bets off. So we can understand where they stand.

It is clear that the intentions of the Soviets are to gut the influence and capacities of the United States in the region and in so doing to destabilise the region and relationships between the United States, Australia and New Zealand and other South Pacific nations. The Opposition, of course, supports the bans on the dumping of nuclear waste and on nuclear testing within the region. However, it is our view-the proper view, I submit-that those bans ought not to be tied in some loose and inadequate way, as they have been, to a treaty of this nature. They should be subject to a separate and substantial convention of their own. In other words, their status ought to be raised and not be tied to this sham, this shabby attempt to delude the Left and the peace vote that the Government has really established a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not succeeding, of course.

—Of course not. As I said at the outset, this Treaty offers the worst of all worlds. It destabilises our area of influence and it reduces our defence capabilities and defence capacity while at the same time offering nothing in a tangible way to reduce the prospects of a nuclear war.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation, other than placing our security at risk, will achieve none of the objectives which it purports to pursue and does not comply with the general guidelines set down by the United States or Britain. Those guidelines are pretty simple and pretty reasonable. They are not guidelines that one could easily disagree with. Included amongst those guidelines is that all states in the region should participate. The truth of the matter is that all the nations in the region do not agree and have not all signed the Treaty. That is a precondition before the Americans will accept it, and quite properly so. One other condition that falls to the ground is that existing security arrangements should not be disturbed. Of course, existing arrangements are disturbed because the very basis of ANZUS is undermined. So to that extent the Americans cannot be expected freely and willingly to sign the protocol. The Americans may well sign the protocol-I am not suggesting they will not-but they will not be doing it because they think it is the best thing to do. So I put it to honourable senators that the Treaty in no way enhances the security of Australia. The substance of the Treaty is in conflict and in my view the flowery prose and promises carved in stone will not be worth a row of beans. In the final analysis, in a conflict the nuclear free zone will be seen for what it is, that is, having no substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address myself to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill 1986. I wish to escape the crude pro-American and anti-American sloganeering into which much of this debate outside this chamber has degenerated. Like some other senators who have spoken on this debate, I too wish to examine the foreign policy context into which the Bill fits and to raise the question whether it fits well or ill. The problem is that there is little serious debate in the electorate about foreign policy and its relation to defence policy. Clearly Australia cannot have a credible foreign policy until it has decided the national security interests which should mould the shape of key foreign policy goals. Therefore, before addressing the merits of this Bill, one must consider first the national security objectives which a Bill such as this should support.

SPEECH.PARA: In my response to the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, I have critically examined the strategic presuppositions on which this review was based. By analysing the nature of our geography and the structure of our economy from the perspective of our proneness to indirect attack, I drew the conclusion that the key to Australia's defence is the security of our sea lines of communication. I made the further point that, although defence of Australia means sea-lane defence, we could not attempt this successfully on our own. We would need to act in co-ordination with neighbours and allies. This means that we need not only a military capacity to contribute to sea-lane defence, but also a foreign policy which would enable us to deploy our forces and to co-ordinate them with friendly forces at points far from the Australian mainland.

What I want to do today, instead of dangerously tinkering at the edges of foreign and defence policy as this Bill does, is to consider what kind of foreign policy would support a defence of the sea-lanes and whether this Bill would help or hinder this project. It is clear that the precondition for a sea-lane defence policy is a foreign policy aimed at deeply engaging Australia in the international relations of the region through which pass the sea-lanes vital to us. Some would argue that we have already met this condition by pointing to Australia's abiding diplomatic interests in our northern and Pacific neighbours. That diplomacy is precisely the point. From the point of view of some in our region, our interest seems like nothing more than diplomacy-that is, words, words, words-and, all too commonly, a cranky, individualistic style of expression at that. So, rather than shoring up friends for the future, Australia has begun to develop a fund of suspicion and contempt in countries whose geographical location and good will bear heavily on our ability to defend this country. The retreat from the region advised by the Dibb report confirms the growing impression among our neighbours that Australia finds it distasteful to have to live in this corner of the world. But even if a natural sense of being culturally unique in the region disposes Australians-quite rightly, in my view-to think of themselves as belonging to the world of European culture, rather than to that of Asian and Pacific cultures, common sense demands that we face facts-namely, that our security is bound up with that of our Asian and Pacific neighbours. This is because a threat to them poses a threat to our vulnerable sea lines of communication.

Sea-lane defence means, therefore, something more fundamental than deploying naval and air forces on or over the relevant waterways. Because control of the lands adjacent to these waters gives a high degree of leverage over them, sea-lane defence entails defending the lands proximate to seas most important to us. Consequently, it is in the interests of our country that our neighbours should be both strong and on close terms with Australia. They should be so close, in fact, that these relations should entail Australia giving concrete expression to the belief that their national security is a component of our national security; for their part, they should come to regard practical Australian support as an important element in their own defence planning.

The contribution, then, of foreign policy to Australian national security ought to be to establish a substantial reciprocal commitment to defending the strategic interests we share with our neighbours. As for defence policy, its contribution should be to provide armed forces capable of conducting independent operations, though in co-ordination with those of our neighbours, in strategically forward areas. The object of this military activity should be to assert some control over waters which are mutually vital to us and to defend those territories whose loss would endanger sea lane security. This kind of `regional deterrence' policy is just plain common sense. It is ridiculous to argue that it is better to fight one's enemies on one's own doorstep than on someone else's. It is absurd to claim that it is superior to delay engaging the enemy until he is in the front yard than to meet him while he is still far off. In any case, an enemy who attacks our sea lanes strikes home indirectly. By hitting the sea lanes an enemy can make us bleed, even fatally, without making an expensive and dangerous direct assault on the Australian continent. Our geography and our reliance on overseas trade make a policy of regional deterrence a strategic imperative. As Professor T. B. Millar recently put it:
The most elementary concepts of defence require that Australia does everything possible to avoid fighting on its own territory except in the last resort.

Critics often made the mistake of confusing this kind of regional deterrence with the old doctrine of `forward defence'. Forward defence meant that Australian forces played the role of a tiny, dependent cog in a great military machine operated by a powerful ally in its own interests. This is not what I am talking about when I speak of `regional deterrence'. What I am proposing is that we employ the `forward' element of the old doctrine, but in a new way. What is new in this proposal is that Australia should have a real defence force of its own, one which by its mere existence would provide Australian governments with a previously unattainable degree of freedom in the conduct of national security policy. Also, `freedom of action' here means a Federal government released from the two major alternative limitations which still circumscribe its power to conduct an integrated national security policy. One is our historical tendency to base defence policy on the fortuitous conjunction of Australia's strategic interests with those of a great and powerful ally. The other arises from the laudable attempt to escape this fatalistic trust in the international constellation of powers. But it ends, alas, in isolationism. Both policies are dangerous for Australia. The former relies on an agreement of interests which might never develop. The latter, which issues logically in a Fortress Australia strategy, commits us to fighting an enemy when it is already too late. My proposal, then, contains a second new element, which is that Australia should have the power and the determination to influence events and not merely to react to them.

Our foreign policy, therefore, should forge links which, in times of danger, will provide the Federal Government with a means of making a co-operative defence of the sea lanes and of providing the opportunity, if need be, of meeting an enemy on the lands which adjoin our sea lines of communication. To make such a foreign policy plausible, Australia needs military forces capable of exploiting the opportunities opened up by diplomacy. Without armed forces able to give effect to regional deterrence, and without the demonstrated political will to use these forces in a forward mode, any foreign policy designed to enhance Australia's real security interests is doomed from the outset to fail. So, while a regional deterrence policy is impossible unless foreign policy paves the way, diplomacy can achieve nothing towards this end if our neighbours see that Australia lacks both the means and the will to defend the strategic interests common to those who live in the region.

Assuming, then, the resolution to develop the right sort of armed forces, what kind of foreign policy objectives will enable those forces effectively to be deployed and, if necessary, to fight on strategically advantageous ground of our own choosing? Australia does not need a lot of new alliances. Those which she has-especially our alliance with the United States and the Five Power Defence Pact-already form a springboard from which to launch a regional deterrence policy. Even the forgotten commitment to Thailand and the Philippines under the South East Asia Collective Defence Treaty could be of service. The Five Power Defence Arrangement and our contribution to its integrated air defence system provide for Australia the most convenient stepping stones into a regional deterrence posture. These structures already provide us with a means of contributing to the defence of the Malacca Straits and of that vital sea-lane which passes through that area into the South China Sea and from thence north-east to Taiwan, Japan and Korea. This route is important to Australia because it carries the oil supplies which fuel the economies of Australia's chief northern Pacific trading partners. Interdiction of these lines would play havoc not only with their economies but also with our own.

Secondly, the Five Power Defence Pact and the bases at Butterworth and Singapore provide Australia-assuming it has the right kind of military forces-with the option of going to the defence of our northern neighbours should they be attacked by some power whose expansion could threaten sea-lane security. Australia could, of course, do nothing about adverse changes in our strategic environment. But since our security depends on the lands and waters to our north not falling under hostile influence or control, it is in Australia's interests to be able to contribute in a forceful way to their defence. Consequently, one object of our foreign policy should be to preserve Australia's capacity for forward basing and forward operation in and around the Malay peninsula. Because the Australian contribution to sea-lane defence in the region is insufficient by itself to preserve our strategic interests, the next objective of our foreign policy should be to develop among the nations of south-east and north-east Asia and the Pacific arrangements which would reinforce sea-lane defence. This would seem to require a series of agreements which would draw Japan, Taiwan and Indonesia together with Five Power Defence Pact members to plan for and to practise sea control operations in the South China Sea and the Malacca Straits. A similar arrangement between Australia and Indonesia ought to be worked out to control the Lombok and Sunda straits and the seas around Australia's north-west.

None of these arrangements requires a treaty or a specific commitment to dispatch forces in time of war to defend any particular stretch of land or water. Rather, we need to set up machinery, perhaps at the chiefs-of-staff level, for conducting joint maritime operations and the routine exercising of the forces and skills required to defend the sea-lanes. This practical co-operation and planning for the defence of common interest should provide as effectively as a formal agreement the kind of mutual confidence and reliance which will dispose regional powers naturally to look for one another's support when confronted by a threat to their mutual strategy interests. The unformulated disposition toward military co-operation which such arrangements would promote is the sine qua non of Australia's new regional deterrence strategy. Unless foreign policy and peacetime military co-operation develop a reasonable expectation of mutual support in time of conflict, an effective defence of Australia's real strategic interests can never be made. Without such expectations, Australia will be deprived of the opportunity to meet our enemies at a distance from our shores and at points strategically most significant to us.

Defence in the South East Asian region should not, however, be our only concern. South East Asia is Australia's outer defence perimeter. Our second line of defence is the stretch of islands which reaches over the roof of Australia from West Irian to Vanuatu and beyond. These command the approaches to eastern Australia and our chief line of communication with the North Pacific and with the United States. As I pointed out in my earlier observations on sea-lane defence, the most important points in this island chain are the passages between the Solomon and Bismarck Seas. To secure the lines of communication passing through this area, friendship with Papua New Guinea is essential. Indeed, given the decision of the Hawke Government not to replace HMAS Melbourne, Papua New Guinea territory assumes an added importance to the defence of Australia. These nearby islands need to serve as our replacement aircraft carrier. Their role should be to make possible effective Australian maritime operations to defend the choke points between the Bismarck and Solomon seas. What Australia, therefore, needs are naval and air bases in Papua New Guinea. To obtain and to preserve a base on Manus Island, as well as access for the Royal Australian Air Force to Port Moresby and Rabaul, should be the major goal of Australian security relations with Papua New Guinea. Australia needs these facilities, not only to exercise control over the Bismarck Sea and the nearby narrow waters, but also to pre-empt the possibility of these bases, and Manus above all, falling into the hands of an unfriendly power.

Given the strategic importance of Papua New Guinea to Australia, the recent decision by the Federal Government to cut our aid to that country is fraught with dangers for Australia's security. On the aid issue, the Hawke Government has made a capital error of judgment. I do not deny the importance of cutting back on government expenditure, particularly in this moment of economic crisis. However, cuts should not be made which have the potential to put our national security at risk. Certainly, cuts in our aid to Papua New Guinea fall into this category, apart from the altruistic questions involved. No excuse or opportunity should ever be given to a Papua New Guinea government to turn away from its close friendship with Australia. More to the point, no foreign power should replace Australia in the interests or the affections of Papua New Guinea. In particular, no power, apart from Australia, should be able to use Papua New Guinea territory for any military purpose.

To achieve these objectives Australia needs to rethink its policy toward Papua New Guinea. A revamped policy toward this country should include, as matter of the highest priority, a generous aid program which will exercise a compelling pro-Australian influence on Papua New Guinea governments and peoples alike. Papua New Guinea needs to be persuaded by our actions that its national security and national development will be best supported by an especially close relationship with Australia. This relationship should include the hosting of Australian bases. Moreover, because Papua New Guinea is vital to Australia, our mutual security interests should be formulated in a defence treaty. This ought to be the primary security goal of Australian foreign policy towards Papua New Guinea. If, however, our foreign policy towards South East Asia and the Pacific, Papua New Guinea particularly, should fail, if our defence efforts in those areas should meet with defeat and if a direct threat to Australia should develop as a result, we would still have a third line of defence. This is where the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities comes into play. The document provides a realistic strategy for the defence of the Australian mainland should all else fail. In this case, our objective will be to defeat the enemy in the sea-air gap.

Let us have done with the Dibb fiction that defence of the `sea-air gap' is a `layered defence': It is a single layer defence. According to the Dibb theory, the enemy must be defeated in its attempt to cross a moat 1,000 nautical miles wide; nor is there any plan to fall back into the continent should our attackers succeed in landing significant forces-not at all. The plan is for the Army to conduct what amounts to a mopping up operation in the vicinity of the coastline against those of the enemy who manage to make it through the moat. The way Dibb proposes for the Army to be deployed does not constitute a second line of defence, it is merely the rear sector of his first. The concept of the `layered defence' as expounded in the Dibb report is little more than a cheap political slogan decked out in scholarly finery or a theatrical costume designed for a Minister for Defence who postures on the national stage as a latter day Australian von Clausewitz. It is a pity that Mr Dibb's considerable learning should have been made use of in this ephemeral and intellectually slippery way.

What I am proposing, though-I hope the Government is able to take this on board-is a real `layered defence', one four layers deep. As I have indicated, the first is in South East Asia, the second is on the line of islands stretching from West Irian to Vanuatu and beyond and the third is in the `sea-air gap'. The fourth line of defence is on the Australian continent itself. Here we can make use of the country's strategic depth to manoeuvre against the invader. With the Dibb strategy, Australia gets one throw of the dice and we cannot afford to lose. With my proposal Australia will have four chances to defeat its enemies and fall-back options should its preferred strategy fail. Australia has nothing to fall back on if the Dibb strategy miscarries-nothing except defeat.

Finally, I turn to the question of our relations with the United States of America. As I have said in earlier comments on this matter, Australia should not seek to rely on the United States to the same degree that it has in the past. Our defence planning should be conducted as if, for all practical purposes, there were no Australia-United States alliance. We must think of having to defend our interests without American help. This means that we cannot assume that the Americans can be relied on to counter strategic imbalances in the approaches to Australia before they mature into threats to our country. The inevitable result of relying thus on others is that Australia must suffer without resistance indirect threats and hostile military action in the area of major strategic value to us. In addition, it means that Australia will defend itself only by fighting on its own ground and hence in circumstances hugely to its disadvantage. Defence planning of this kind is an invitation to our enemies to use armed force against Australia.

The only rational alternative policy is for Australia to conduct an offensive defence strategy in which, in combination with our neighbours and regional trading partners, we will attempt to forestall or foil the development of indirect threats before they mature against our sea lines of communication. If in the end we receive US help, well and good. This will make our forward dispositions all the more powerful. Indeed, though we must not depend on American aid, Australia's preparations for regional deterrence will attract American support more powerfully because these preparations have the further advantages of contributing both to regional defence and to the security of the Western interest in the region. This is because the American defence role in our zone of strategic interest is, in part, a function of the commitment of America's closest regional allies to the defence of mutual regional interests.

On the other hand, if Australia is not prepared to become militarily engaged in the area which embraces its most important strategic assets, the Americans have a disincentive to engage themselves there. This is a point that Association of South East Asian Nations countries well appreciate and it is why they want Australia to be effectively and actively involved militarily in the region. They know that a forward role for Australia in the region acts as a powerful magnet to US engagement. This is a point that Australian planners should better understand, especially in view of re-emerging popular isolationist instincts in the United States. With regard to the Americans then, our rule ought to be: Plan as if everything depends on ourselves and we shall have allies, plan as if everything depends on allies and we shall end up fighting on our own ground and alone. In the light of this axiom, the role of Australian foreign policy should be to pave the way into our South East Asian and Pacific front line.

These considerations should lead the Government and the Parliament to ask these questions about the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill. Does the Government want to have its cake and eat it too? Does the Government want the kudos of being nuclear free while playing host to the nuclear Navy of the United States and other elements supportive of US strategic nuclear forces? Is this not irrational and dangerous? Does this danger not lie in the fact that the Government, having made an emotive issue of the term `nuclear free zone', has established a springboard from which groups can launch an actual and premature nuclear free zone which would debar both nuclear armed and nuclear powered vessels from Australian and other Pacific ports? In the absence of any realistic policy to defend our interests in the region by regional deterrence or conventional means, does the Bill not promote the possibility of an actual and premature nuclear free zone and would this not destroy Australia's connection with the United States, whose support in times of crisis we ought not to deny ourselves? Would it not also disturb security in the Pacific and Asian region to the detriment of multilateral and verifiable disarmament, include nuclear disarmament, and world peace?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its unanimous support of the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill. I thank the majority of the Senate for its clearly indicated support of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill. Clearly, the arguments, such as they were, really boiled down to arguments about the latter Bill and it is to those that I will confine my reply. The passage of this Bill will clear the way for Australia's ratification of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. That Treaty is an initiative of Australia, specifically of the Hawke Government, and it is an initiative of which we are very proud. It expresses the strong community of interest which members of the South Pacific Forum share in environmental and security matters and reflects the deeply felt and long-standing concerns in our region about nuclear testing, the ocean dumping of nuclear waste and the horizontal proliferation of nuclear weapons. The Treaty commits all the parties to important obligations in those areas. It also reflects, in the words of the preamble that have been quoted once before in this debate, but which deserve repetition, the determination of the people of the South Pacific:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the bounty and beauty of the land and sea in their region shall remain the heritage of their peoples and their desendants in perpetuity to be enjoyed by all in peace;

Seven other South Pacific Forum countries have already ratified that Treaty-Fiji, Cook Islands, Niue, Tuvalu, Kiribati, Western Samoa and New Zealand. Eight ratifications are required for it to enter into force. The Treaty thus awaits Australia's ratification and that ratification will be forthcoming this week, shortly after the passage of this Bill. As I have said, that will be a splendid achievement not only for Australia but for the entire South Pacific region.

The primary attack on the Bill has taken the form of an attack by the Opposition parties, joined by Senator Harradine, on the strategic consequences alleged to flow from it. I do not think it is appropriate to turn this debate, as Senator Harradine tried to do, into a full scale analysis of Australian foreign policy, defence policy, the Dibb Review into Australia's Defence Capabilities, regional defence and the large miscellany of issues that are necessarily tied up in considering that. But it is important to recognise just what the Opposition, in particular, is saying about this Bill and why the Opposition, in particular, is opposing it. The reason why it is opposing it, primarily and overwhelmingly, is that the Liberal Party and the National Party favour the installation on Australian soil of nuclear weapons. They favour home porting, they favour the stationing of weapons, they favour the internal transport of weapons and they favour the storage of weapons on Australian soil. That was made absolutely clear by Mr Peacock in his initial Press statement back on 7 August 1985 responding to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty when its terms were first announced. It has subsequently become clear in the contributions of Mr Peacock and others to the House of Representatives debate and the contributions of all the major Opposition speakers today.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are misrepresenting the Opposition.

—If I am misrepresenting the Opposition I would be delighted to be told where. Let me quote, for example, from what Mr Peacock said on 7 August. He had not been provided with a copy of the Treaty at that stage but he was particularly concerned that it could prohibit home porting within the zone. I quote not from a newspaper report but from his own Press release, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Any reading of newspaper reports of the proposal-and other information I've had-indicates that this will be the likely interpretation of the Treaty which bans the installation and storage of nuclear weapons within the zone.

I call upon the Prime Minister to immediately and categorically give an assurance to the Australian people that the Treaty, as drafted, will not prohibit home porting by the United States within the zone.
This would be an act of folly.

Of course, home porting is no more and no less than the installation and storage of nuclear weapons on Australian soil. That is the position of the Opposition, it is the position of the Liberal and National parties, and it is a position which is profoundly at odds with the views of the Government, and I believe, the views of the Australian people. We make no apology whatsoever for our complete opposition to the stationing of nuclear weapons on Australian territory. As to home porting, the Fraser Government sought to interest the United States of America in such a proposition in relation to Stirling in Western Australia but the United States made it clear that it was not interested. The United States bases in the Philippines are secure, in any event, until 1991. Moreover, if any need to relocate them were proven in due course, all the current discussion in the United States is directed at points east and north of the Philippines, not south, since to move further south would render it more difficult for the United States to honour its North Pacific obligations.

It is simply not the case that there is any concern of any measurable kind in the United States about the strategic implications in the region of the adoption of this legislation. I am not saying that there is no concern about nuclear free zones as such and the precedential status that the creation of a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific would have elsewhere. But in terms of the immediate strategic interests which the United States has obviously designed to protect and which we are pledged to safeguard, there is no way in which that will be undermined in any way. The Treaty provides all that the United States requires for its strategic mobility in the region. It in no way restricts any current or contemplated United States military activity in the region. United States officials themselves-and this has been the subject not just of private discussion but of congressional testimony-have acknowledged the effort that was made in drafting the Treaty to take into account United States strategic interests in the region.

It is important to appreciate-I do not think very many people in the Opposition do-that the Treaty of Rarotonga and its protocols simply do not cut across acknowledgment of the central importance of stable nuclear deterrence. That is one of the reasons why some people say that the Treaty does not go as far as they would like it to. But that is a different point made for different reasons. The point I am dealing with at the moment is the concern about its strategic impact. One needs to appreciate that the Treaty explicitly upholds the sovereign right of each party to make its own security arrangements and decisions on port access for naval vessels in transit, including access to airports for military aircraft. The formulations are drafted to permit military exercises and other navigation within territorial waters of Treaty parties. There is a full respect for transit rights for ships and aircraft in accordance with customary international law and the law of the sea. In addition to high seas freedoms such as navigation and overflight, the Treaty specifically protects rights of innocent passage through the territorial sea and rights of passage for ships and aircraft through archipelagic waters and straits used for international navigation and all this is quite clear and explicit in this Treaty, unlike the Treaty of Tlatelolco where these things were left inexplicit and generated some concern of a kind that might have led to thin edge of the wedge arguments of the kind that in turn we have heard from Senator Harradine, and so on.

I suppose that a few other things are worth mentioning for the record. The Treaty fully upholds the principle that littoral states cannot purport to legislate for oceans or otherwise beyond their internationally recognised legal jurisdiction and in this it is stronger and clearer again than the Tlatelolco Treaty. It does not proscribe the peaceful uses of nuclear energy and, unlike the Tlatelolco Treaty, it goes further in the other direction and does not permit so-called peaceful nuclear explosions. The point is acknowledged that it is very difficult in practice to distinguish between the two. I further make the point, again to meet this concern about strategic implications, that the protocols of the Treaty were amended between draft and finalisation as a result of forum consultations with United States officials to include a withdrawal clause in conformity with other arms control treaties to which the United States is a party.

I simply do not believe that there is any foundation for the argument that the Treaty will operate to reduce strategic mobility, undermine the principle of nuclear deterrence, or in some other way weaken those larger, Western strategic interests to which Australia is necessarily bound. Nor does the Treaty in any way weaken Australia's security. It maintains all the important benefits and advantages long accruing to Australia from ANZUS and adds to them such important elements as undertakings by our South Pacific neighbours that they will not allow nuclear weapons to be stationed on their respective territories and, through the protocols, will attract legally binding guarantees that the nuclear weapons states will not use or threaten to use nuclear weapons against Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —When do you expect the protocols to be signed?

—That is a matter for discussion and negotiation at the moment. As far as the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and China are concerned there seems to be no particular difficulty about them. France is--
—I am talking about our allies-Great Britain and America.

—I do not think the honourable senator is talking about our allies being likely to use or threaten to use nuclear weapons against Australia. But the two countries that are proving to be taking the longest to come to grips with these issues are the United States and France.
—As you know, the Russians have a caveat on their protocol.

—We will debate that issue at a later time. For the moment it is perfectly clear that the terms of the Treaty and the protocols attached to it are such that not only are Western strategic interests not threatened, not only is United States strategic mobility not in any way threatened, not only is the capacity to mobilise fully and effectively in the event of a major confrontation not threatened, but also Australia's own interests are manifestly advanced in the ways that I have just described.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick went on, in another assault on the legislation, to say that there was nothing in the Treaty, nor in this Bill picking it up and applying it, which broke any new ground in international law, in particular as far as the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons was concerned. He argued that anything that was worth saying or doing was already said and done in the context of the Non-Proliferation Treaty. But that is simply not to appreciate fully the extent of the ground covered by this Treaty. Let me indicate six or seven ways in which this Treaty breaks new ground in international law. It prescribes more explicit conditions for the export of nuclear material than does the Non-Proliferation Treaty. The South Pacific Treaty provides fullscope safeguards restricting the export of nuclear materials even to nuclear weapon states whereas the Non-Proliferation Treaty does not prescribe the safeguards requirements in anything like the same detail. Again, as I have already said, this Treaty prohibits peaceful nuclear explosions in a way that other similar treaties in the past have not. It prohibits the facilitation of nuclear testing, which, of course, is not something addressed in the NPT. It prohibits parties from dumping of radioactive waste, and in that respect it is complementary to the South Pacific regional and environmental program convention, which has just been finalised, as I indicated, a few days ago. It prohibits the facilitation of the dumping of radioactive wastes as distinct from just the dumping itself. It provides more detailed definitions of the stationing of nuclear explosive devices than does the Treaty of Tlatelolco or any similar treaty otherwise previously put in place. It establishes-this is particularly important-very high standards of verification and control requirements and, as such, is a model for other arms control measures. These are all ways in which this Treaty does go beyond the NPT and any similar previous measures and all ways in which this Treaty does break new ground.

The only remaining contribution I think I ought to deal with quickly-although no doubt some of these canards will be trotted out again in the Committee stage-is Senator Sanders's quite extraordinarily irresponsible discussion, if it can be dignified with that description, of aspects of our present uranium sales policy and in particular the question of uranium sales to France. I was not fully able to focus on everything that he said and I have not yet seen a Hansard report of it, but there are at least four spectacular misstatements from Senator Sanders that came tumbling out in the few minutes that I was listening to him. The only thing I can say for Senator Sanders is that he always, when challenged with these things, gracefully acknowledges that he was telling fibs or exaggerating or behaving in a thoroughly coloured and tendentious fashion. But it would be helpful if in the future, when corrected on these matters, he did not go on repeating them as the gospel thereafter.

Let me just quickly correct the record. I refer, firstly, to the story about the Australian Government contemplating uranium sales to Taiwan, as a result of some wildly over-optimistic British Petroleum internal memorandum being leaked, as it was a few weeks ago. As Senator Sanders would well appreciate, that particular story was immediately and vigorously quashed by public statements, both by the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) and by myself, making it clear that there was no safeguards arrangement in existence between ourselves and Taiwan and under those circumstances it was simply inconceivable that there could be any contemplation of exporting uranium to that particular country.

The second thing we had was this extraordinary proposition based on my answer in the Senate of 20 August when I referred to `Roxby Downs and new supplies coming on to the market'-something that was misdescribed in the Daily Hansard, for easily explicable reasons, as `new suppliers coming on to the market'. It was a misunderstanding of what I had said, which I immediately corrected later in that same Question Time, making it clear that the three mines policy remained intact and there was no question of any move away from that; there would be no `new suppliers' coming on to the market so long as the Australian Labor Party's policy remained as it is, which we had every intention of ensuring. Notwithstanding that correction later that same Question Time-and again, I think, perhaps the next day, just to make it absolutely clear-Senator Sanders quite shamelessly has trotted out that particular misquotation again in his contribution to this debate.

Then we have had the tale of the Superphenix reactor and the alleged contribution to that of Australian nuclear material. The truth of the matter is that Australian origin material has not been used in the Superphenix fast breeder reactor, either by way of an initial fuel or by way of, in its depleted form--

TALK.START.PARA: —You said `to the best of my knowledge' before. Are you saying that none has ever been used?

—Had the honourable senator's statement in the Parliament been similarly qualified, I might have treated it with a little more respect. All I can say is that so far as depleted Australian uranium is concerned, it is the case that the enrichment process has a byproduct of depleted uranium which possesses less than a third of the radioactivity of natural uranium. The enrichment that is done in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in respect of uranium destined ultimately for Finland does result in some of that depleted uranium coming back to France. But the truth of the matter is that that depleted uranium resulting from Soviet enrichment is stored under a fee arrangement at a French stockpile where it is clearly marked as being of Australian origin and where it is subject to International Atomic Energy Agency inspections and Australian Safeguards Office accounting procedures. I can be as sure as I am about anything in this whole area of safeguards and ASO procedures and nuclear accounting that none of that Australian depleted uranium is being used in that particular reactor in that way. It is also the case that we are certainly not aware of any Australian origin nuclear material being used otherwise in that particular reactor.
—RWE?
—The honourable senator keeps talking about RWE, but there is no information that I have to give any support, nourishment or sustenance to that particular assertion.
—They have a 10 per cent interest in Superphenix.

—That may be, but Australian origin nuclear material is tracked right through the system in a way that I know Senator Sanders simply cannot bring himself to understand or to come to grips with. I am perfectly happy that he goes and spends a day in the Australian Safeguards Office in Sydney-an invitation I have offered to him before which he still has not taken me up on because he is afraid that if he does so he will actually learn what happens and lose some wonderful rhetorical lines which he has been able to trot out in complete ignorance and in complete indifference to the truth of the matter in this particular chamber. I have made the point, quite apart from the Superphenix and the whole fast breeder matter, that there is a complete separation in any event of the fuel cycles in France for the production of highly enriched uranium for weapons production purposes. The weapons grade enriched uranium is produced in France at the Pierrelatte facility. I have said as much in answer to questions in this place on 22 August; I have said it elsewhere and I will repeat it again now: The civil nuclear enrichment facility to which Australian uranium is transferred is located at Tricastin. For operational reasons, including that of nuclear criticality, it is not possible to produce high enriched uranium in a civil plant. This physical separation at one of the most sensitive stages of the fuel cycle provides an additional measure of assurance.

SPEECH.PARA: For a whole variety of reasons, what we know about where the material actually is, what we know about where the French processing is carried out for particular purposes, and all the material on the record that I have referred to over and again, simply makes nonsense of the kinds of allegations which are randomly and cavalierly made by Senator Sanders every time he gets up and opens his mouth on this particular topic. I am trying to anticipate matters that will arise in the Committee stage debate again no doubt in order to shorten that Committee stage debate. Beyond that, there are many other points, some of them equally tendentious, that have been made by other speakers, but bearing in mind the constraints of time, I will not pursue them at this stage. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) during his speech.
—Please proceed.

—Senator Evans claimed that the Opposition wanted to see the stationing of nuclear weapons in Australia. He claimed that that was a view that we held. I claim that that is a misrepresentation of my remarks because, in speaking on behalf of the Opposition in this debate yesterday, I made it quite clear that our concern about the prohibition of stationing of nuclear weapons, which is required by the Treaty and by this legislation, is a matter of concern to the Opposition in the event of an emergency occurring or Australia being at peril or at war, and that in those circumstances we would be calling upon our ally, the United States of America, to assist us. That is the very foundation of the ANZUS alliance. If war occurred we might want American aircraft and warships to be deployed out of Australian ports and airfields. Those ships and aircraft may well carry nuclear weapons that may be vital for the defence of Australia. It was that point and that point alone that I wanted to make when I said that we were concerned about the effect of this Treaty which would prevent that happening in time of war. I specifically drew the distinction between the operation of the alliance in time of war and in time of peace. We acknowledge that this Treaty does not prevent normal visits but in time of war it may well render the assistance we would be calling upon of no value to us.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want briefly to return to the point I raised in my personal explanation at the end of the second reading debate. Under the Standing Orders I was not able to do any more than simply cite the misrepresentation that the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, who is at the table, made about the speech that I had previously made. I pointed out that I had made it quite clear that my objection, speaking on behalf of the Opposition, was to the very wide definition of stationing of nuclear weapons in the circumstances that could arise in time of emergency or, indeed, war. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty may prevent Australia from being able to exercise the full value of the ANZUS alliance. Mr Temporary Chairman, I really cannot hear myself speak in this chamber-
—Order! There is too much noise coming from my right.

—Now that Senator Richardson has left we may have a little more silence and attention. During Senator Evans's speech in reply to the second reading debate he claimed that in a statement that Mr Peacock had issued, as shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and on behalf of the Opposition, he had said that Australia opposes the Treaty because it would prevent the home porting of United States warships in Australia and that this therefore means that the Opposition favours the stationing of nuclear weapons in Australia. Mr Peacock, in the House of Representatives on 20 August 1986 when leading for the Opposition in the debate on the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill, referred on page 356 of Hansard to the definition of the stationing of nuclear weapons, which is prohibited under the Treaty, and what is meant by it. He referred to the Treaty's definition of `stationing' as including `transportation on land or inland waters, stockpiling, storage, installation and deployment'.
—You should be doing this on the third reading.

—For the benefit of Senator Georges, there would have been no need for me to be speaking now or quoting anything had it not been for the Minister who is at the table, Senator Gareth Evans, deliberately seeking to misrepresent the position of the Opposition when he replied to the second reading debate. That is why I am speaking. Mr Peacock went on:

SPEECH.PARA: This is an extraordinarily wide definition that in effect could strait-jacket successive Australian governments from offering home porting facilities to the United States Navy or base facilities to the United States nuclear-capable aircraft or nuclear-capable ground units.

TALK.START.PARA: —QED.
—Senator Evans should listen as I read on. Mr Peacock continued:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not the argument of the Opposition that we want to stockpile-

TALK.START.PARA: —You have read enough to make the point.
—I will start again. Mr Peacock continued:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not the argument of the Opposition that we want to stockpile nuclear weapons in this country, but we will not abide a clause which says that in time of peril to this country, need, war or a threat to our security, if our allies want to enter our ports-home ports, if one likes-or deploy troops, they will be forbidden to do so by this Bill because of the definition clause defining stationing as including transportation on land or inland waters and deployment. If we were in the perilous situation of asking the United States to come to our aid, is it to be thought that this legislation is to override ANZUS?

That is exactly the sort of situation in which this Treaty would override ANZUS. For the Government to say that this Treaty and this Bill have no effect on our existing defence arrangements and the basic security of this country under ANZUS is quite false. They certainly do have such an effect because of the wide definition of `stationing' which I have referred to, which has been referred to in the debate earlier and which has been referred to very clearly by Mr Peacock. Mr Peacock made perfectly clear in the debate in the House of Representatives what the Opposition's objection is. It is not that the Opposition favours the stationing of nuclear weapons in Australia. It certainly does not. Senator Evans has used this debate to misrepresent totally the position of the Opposition as expressed by Mr Peacock in the other place and by other senators and me on behalf of the Opposition in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my desire to prolong this debate but an important point is at issue. I am delighted that Senator Durack read into the record the passage that he did-not from page 356 but from 358 of the Hansard of 20 August-because it makes my point exactly. `Stationing' is defined, as Senator Durack accurately recounted, as `transportation on land or island waters, stockpiling, storage, installation and deployment'. The only one of those things that Mr Peacock ruled out in what Senator Durack quoted him as saying was not the Opposition's policy was stockpiling. What he quite explicitly left in was stationing in the sense of transportation on land or inland waters, storage, installation and deployment. In two explicit references he also indicated support for the concept of home porting. So it is the case that the Opposition does support the installation, the storage, the deployment and the transportation of nuclear weapons on Australian soil. Mr Peacock has said as much; it is there on page 358. My case rests.
—A further misrepresentation of the-

—Order! Senator Durack, the Chair has exercised some leniency with respect to the matter we have been discussing. I have allowed time on both sides. I suggest that subsequent speakers direct their attention to the clauses before the Committee.
