I ask the Minister whether I am wrong in that. Is this just a oncer to balance this Budget, or is Labor's policy now to export to France? How can the Labor Party say that its policy is not to export uranium to France when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said that its previous policy to ban it was just a shop window, that it had no legs to run and was just an empty gesture? Is it Labor's policy to ban it and is it an empty gesture? One cannot have it both ways. The Prime Minister is very facile on both sides of the argument and has some skills on this. He has schizophrenic policies in this regard and has said quite clearly that the policy Labor embarked upon was a policy of gesture, of shop window. He said that it could not be enforceable, that it meant nothing to France, it did not punish France. Far more importantly, let it be said, and I repeat it, that what that meant, and what the Democrats are now proposing, is to say to France: `No, you cannot buy our uranium, which will be monitored and you can't put it into weapons, but you can shop all over the world and get it on the cheap, where there is no such monitoring and you can put it into weapons'. What kind of disarmament policy is that? What kind of hypocritical policy is it?

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister whether he will help me: Is it the policy of the Labor Party to prohibit the export of uranium to France? Should France understand that at some time in the near or distant future this will stop? Are we to say to those who want uranium from Australia: `No, you cannot have it from us, even though we have the strongest safeguards on earth and we can ensure that you use it only for peaceful purposes, but you are at liberty to shop anywhere you like, get it as secretly as you like, and get it without safeguards'? I cannot think of a more disastrous policy, and that is what the Democrats' amendment would lead to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised at the aggressive way in which Senator Sir John Carrick supports the cause of peace. There is a contradiction there. The Liberal Party's problem is that it has reached the position of peace through strength. Immediately one takes that position, we are all endangered. The practical end of that approach to peace is that we will continue to arm ourselves in order to match the armament of our opponents. I am not misrepresenting the position. That is the basis of our disagreement. The Opposition has no trust or faith or hope and suggests that the world should continue to arm and that we should continue to be a part of the arms race.
—On the contrary; our policy is total disarmament.

—I know the honourable senator's views and I know the policy of his Party, and I know what he has said here today-peace, but peace through strength. In the circumstances in which we are placed that policy is disastrous. Fortunately, there is a breakthrough. There are some who are beginning to believe that they can take a unilateral position in order to establish some reversal of the present acceleration in the arms race.
—That is not Labor Party policy.

—Could we put Labor Party policy to one side? I find that difficult to deal with, just as I find it difficult to deal with Senator Sir John Carrick. All the statements the honourable senator has made concerning uranium and the use of uranium lead to the conclusion that we should ban the mining and exploitation of uranium. Everything he has suggested seems to indicate that we are dealing with an extremely dangerous element. The best way to deal with it is to make certain that it is not used at all.
—That is not Labor policy.

—I have asked the Opposition to leave Labor Party policy on one side and to look at human policy as it ought to be. The honourable senator in his argument even mentioned banks, reserves of plutonium which we are to collect and put to one side and take out of the cycle. I suggest that we should not even commence the cycle, and then we would have no problems with any part of this debate.
—Three hundred nuclear reactors.
—Well, let us put them down. They are starting to run down now.
—You are nice and warm.
—What is Senator Walters suggesting?
—I am saying that people need it for energy.

—I think we are being diverted somewhat. I remember Senator Sir John Carrick making a remark in support of the use of uranium for peaceful purposes for generation of electricity by saying: `Otherwise people will freeze in the dark'.
—No, I did not.

—The honourable senator said that people would freeze in the dark, and he used another term, if I recall, that was unparliamentary; but it was quite incorrect. The risks of entering into the use and cycling of uranium lead to the whole world being placed at risk. The problem is that although an understanding might be reached by the super-powers, the major powers, recognising now as they do the possibility of human destruction, the problem is that other powers are beginning to exploit and to develop their own weapons. The only way to stop that is to stop the flow of uranium, to stop mining, to exclude it from human activity, as we have excluded other dangerous products from human activity. Poison gas is a classic example.
—They are using it in Iran.
—Yes, perhaps, but that is not a justification for its use. Let us take it that that is one product we ban.
—What about acid rain?

—Acid rain can be dealt with in a generation, but the consequences of the use of uranium may take centuries to recover from, if ever. Do not let us start idle comparisons. All I am suggesting is that the disagreement is that Liberal policy as to the achievement of peace places us at continued risk. The possibility of our walking together to achieve peace can be achieved only if Senator Sir John Carrick changes his views. He might suggest that I should change my views, but I am in the pure position of saying `Not on-no violence, no armaments, no conflict'. That is my position.
—No, that is the Democrats' position.

—No, it is my position. The Democrats have nothing to do with the position I take on these matters. It seems to me that Senator Sir John Carrick is not prepared to accept the real concept of peace; that is my argument with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —One cannot help but be drawn to the conclusion that these amendments by the Australian Democrats, which call for the cessation of the export of uranium to France so long as it continues to test in the South Pacific zone, are nothing more than an empty gesture-in fact, a token gesture which will have absolutely no effect. It seems to me that it is typical of the pathetic, pious amendments that more and more we are finding the Democrats seeking to move in a desperate attempt to hang on to what small constituency they still have within the community. One would have thought that if they were genuine, serious and real in their wishes, hopes and ambitions for the cessation of sales of uranium from Australia they would have widened their amendment. Why do the amendments, as they stand at the moment, refer only to the export of uranium to France? Clearly the Democrats' intention is to seek to embarrass and highlight the dichotomy and difficulties for those on the Left of the Australian Labor Party. From my observations I would say that so far they have failed badly. One is moved to feel that they are rather irresponsible rascals. They love to spend but they hate to cut. One might be moved to observe that perhaps the Democrats are the biggest spending, lowest taxing party in the Parliament because they do not have the responsibility that others have. They do not have the need to balance judgments, considerations and competing interests.

SPEECH.PARA: In rebuttal, in part, of the argument that has been put to us by the Democrats, I refer to the report entitled `Disarmament and Arms Control in the Nuclear Age' put down by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, perhaps the most definitive report put down in many years on this and a whole range of matters relating to the nuclear cycle. In doing so, I recall that the one party which did not appear before the Committee to give evidence was the Australian Democrats. We heard not a word from them. We wrote to the then Leader of the Democrats, Senator Chipp, and asked him whether he would appear to give evidence and justify his arguments. Would he support his arguments? Would he in any way make a contribution to this report by way of evidence? But his response was deafening in its silence. We hear them here in the Senate, but not before a committee where they would be required to give evidence and be cross-examined.

TALK.START.PARA: —And where the facts would come out.

—Where the facts would come out and their superficial arguments would be pricked like a balloon and collapse around their ears. At least at that stage the People for Nuclear Disarmament gave us evidence. I make no judgments about that; people who are concerned to make judgments can read the evidence and draw their own conclusions. At least they gave us evidence, inadequate as it might have been. I notice that the Democrats are at least present today and I ask honourable senators, as I asked earlier: Where is Senator Vallentine? Why has she abrogated her responsibilities and abandoned her constituents from Western Australia who in good faith voted for her-those 53,000 who gave her their primary votes? Where is their representative today? She led them to believe that she would represent them in this Parliament, in this chamber, with her voice and more particularly with her vote. Where is she? We now have the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill 1986 before us, the one piece of legislation that is her reason for being here. It is the reason for the very existence of her Party. It is her piece de resistance. This piece of legislation is what she is all about. Where is she? She is on a private trip to New Zealand and she has 53,000 voters in Western Australia hanging on every single word that she is not saying.
—That's more than you've got, mate.

—The vast majority of her second preferences went to Noel Ashley Crichton-Browne, so obviously some of the Western Australian voters are schizophrenic. I find it absolutely disgraceful that Senator Vallentine took their faith, confidence and goodwill, used it to get into this chamber, and has now flitted off to New Zealand at a time when she should be standing up and articulating the aspirations and wishes of those people whom she purports to represent. No wonder they feel disillusioned and deserted.
—They will still vote for her.

—They will not vote for her next time in enough numbers to have her returned in either a double dissolution or a half Senate election. I promise you that. Last time we were too busy getting rid of the Democrats in Western Australia; next time we will settle on her.
—Is that a threat?
—That is not a threat; it is a promise.
—She got elected; you got appointed. There is a vast difference.
—I did not get appointed. I was elected.
—You were appointed to a place from where you could not be defeated.
—Of course I could. She was No. 1 on her ticket and I was No. 1 on mine. What is the difference?
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Georges, please cease your dialogue.
—I refer the Committee to page 545 of this profound report. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The arguments in favour of Australia continuing to mine and export uranium were generally supported by the report of the ASTEC inquiry, which concluded inter alia that:
(a) Australia is best able to make a significant contribution to the cause of non-proliferation if it is actively involved in the nuclear fuel cycle.

Australia is needed in the non-proliferation debate to a greater extent than one would normally expect. This is due in part to the considerable reserves of uranium within Australia and Australia's record as a reliable supplier under strict controls and in part because Australia has continually sought to provide practical solutions to problems facing the non-proliferation regime.
This report is attested to and signed by the Government and the Opposition-both. The report goes on to say-with the support of the Government and coalition members and senators:
There will continue to be market opportunities for Australian uranium, and withdrawal of Australian supply would make little difference to the continued nuclear energy industry.
The report continues:

The Committee accepts that there is no shortage of uranium in the world to supply fuel to the civil nuclear industry and that the industry can proceed whether or not Australia is a supplier. It therefore supports the view that cutting off the supplies of uranium will not have any effect in reducing the number of nuclear weapons in the world.
That is a direct reflection of the views that have been put by Senator Sir John Carrick so far. He is quite right and so is this report. The report continues:
The principal impact of withdrawal of Australian uranium-
and I hope that the Democrats are listening to this-
will be felt by Australia; through the loss of potential and existing export earnings and through our diminished influence in the International Atomic Energy Agency and other related bodies.
I recall that we are one of the founding board members of that agency. That is where we have our influence. The report goes on:

The Committee supports the conclusion of the ASTEC report that, on balance, the non-proliferation regime is better served by Australia remaining a supplier of uranium ore. Australian uranium is supplied under very stringent safeguards. As noted by the ASTEC report, there is reasonable evidence that the imposition of these safeguards has not deterred prospective purchases of Australian uranium. Indeed, their acceptance may encourage other suppliers to insist on comparable conditions.

The very fact that we have those safeguards means that we are able to sell our uranium. In no way are people inhibited in their purchases as a result of those conditions. In fact, the opposite is true. Perhaps other suppliers will be encouraged to provide the same safeguards. I will read the last paragraph of the Committee's report on this aspect and I recommend it as bed time reading for Senator Georges. It says:

Australia's role as an exporter has enabled us to play an important role in establishing and developing the present nuclear non-proliferation regime. The Committee accepts the view of both ASTEC and the Government that withdrawal from the nuclear fuel cycle would reduce our influence in the IAEA, which plays a key role in the non-proliferation regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does the minority report say?
—There is a minority report at the back which Senator Georges is welcome to read. I am seeking to put the view of the majority of people, embracing both the Government and the Opposition.
—How about waving the minority report around now?

—If you look deep in the report you will find it there, Senator Georges. I am seeking to reflect the views of the majority of members of Parliament, either senators or members. That view clearly is that Australia and the industry generally are advantaged by the mining and export of uranium, whether it be to France or any other country. There is an abundance of uranium ore available and, whether it is supplied by Australia or anywhere else, it will in no way inhibit France's capacity to receive the ore, process it and ultimately use it for whatever purposes it so desires. As long as Australia uses its safeguards to that extent France is inhibited. I put it to the Committee that this amendment does nothing for this legislation. The legislation in itself is inadequate, incompetent and does not do what it pretends to do. The very title of the legislation is misleading because the South Pacific is not a nuclear free zone; it is not even a nuclear weapons free zone. In fact, it is simply a zone that in some part puts some inhibition on the United States and nothing else. The essence of the Bill is that it prevents home porting for American forces. I see no merit in the amendment and I have no doubt that it will be defeated.

—I have listened to the debate so far with interest. It seems to me that we are moving away from the issue, which is the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill. People have got up to declare that they are interested in peace. I accept that everyone who has said that is sincere. The process by which people believe peace can be achieved varies. Senator Sir John Carrick's record proves his sincerity in proclaiming an appetite for peace. The Australian Democrats have demonstrated again and again in this chamber that they are sincere in desiring peace. Along with everybody else, I sincerely desire peace. People have criticised the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill and said that it has shortcomings. No doubt it has, but at least it is some attempt to proceed down a path that would enable peace to come to this world. It may be insufficient; it may be capable of improvement and what have you, but at least it is a concrete contribution towards a better world. That is the Bill we are debating. People want to extend into this debate their own particular recipe for peace. The banning of uranium sales to France may be a way of doing that. This should be debated at some time in the future.
—This afternoon.

—I am a great respecter of Senator Georges but at least if we get this Bill through today it will be some attempt to move along the path to peace, whereas if the amendments are carried the Bill will be put off into the future. If that happens the Bill may well suffer the fate of many other Bills. For example, the Cheques Bill has been 2 1/2 years in being passed. We can certainly sit around here making all sorts of debating points, but if we want to give the people of Australia something in this International Year of Peace we will pass this Bill before Christmas. I greatly respect Senator Sanders. He has raised some debating points, as he is entitled to. But say I said that we would pass this Bill as long as a provision to abolish sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act were included-an abolition I am very much devoted to. He would say that this was irrelevant and off the point. Perhaps he would say that, although the abolition of those sections was a crucial issue, it was not appropriate to be debated in the present context.
—How about a meaningful treaty next year?

—Senator Sanders has a good point. It is in the Australian Labor Party policy, as stated at the last conference, that there will be no sale of uranium to France unless and until it stops experimenting with nuclear weapons in the Pacific. There is no doubt about that being in the policy, but it is also in the policy that there shall be a South Pacific nuclear free zone treaty. That is what this Bill delivers.
—Even if it doesn't do anything.

—Senator Haines wants absolute perfection. I believe that we will get peace in the world but only by taking a step at a time. There will not be a dramatic flash of light and suddenly peace thereafter. At least this legislation is a measure by which we on this side of the chamber can say that we have made an attempt to get a peaceful world. People may say that we should have done more. Of course we should have done more but at least we have done something practical, whereas every other suggestion made here today does not lead to that. The passing of this Bill as presented at least will do something towards peace. It is in conformity with the Labor Party policy. The Democrats want to attach other things to it. They are entitled to attempt that. In my view their amendments are not relevant to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill. Uranium sales to France can be discussed later. I advise honourable senators to get back to what is before the Committee and to pass the Bill. The other issue can be debated later, when the Labor Party policy can be pointed to and all the aspects of that issue can be raised. I do not say this in any condemnatory fashion because I understand what the Democrats are trying to do subjectively, but objectively the approach they are taking is delaying a Bill which makes some contribution-it might be only small compared with what is ideal-towards peace not only in the South Pacific but throughout the world generally. Some concrete contributions to peace are better than an ideal still-born.
—I have found the debate very interesting. At last we have really got it on record that the Australian Democrats are far more left than the Left of the Australian Labor Party.
—Ask John Siddons.

—Yes. Senator Sanders has been telling us that we should get rid of the ANZUS alliance and all the American bases from Australia, that we should not allow any American warships in our ports, that the South Pacific nuclear free zone is a good idea, that we should abandon the Western alliances, and anything else that came into his head. The Democrats have really gone the whole circle. They are far more left than even Senator Georges.
—Who, me?
—Yes, the Democrats are far more left than Senator Georges. There is one very big difference between Senator Georges and the Australian Democrats.
—What is that?

—I believe that Senator Georges is very sincere. I believe that Senator Georges wants peace as much as I do, and he should give me the courtesy of acknowledging that peace as much as he does. We may want to go about it a different way but we both want peace more than anything else in the world. Senator Georges has given us a dissertation today on what the peace movement is doing. He says that the peace movement is out to change attitudes in the world.
—Well, it has succeeded.

—Senator Georges says the peace movement has succeeded in changing attitudes. He makes it sound as though the peace movement is something new, yet he sat here last night and listened to me give a history of what happened after World War I. He sat there and either closed his mind to what I said or ignored it. I pointed out very clearly that the peace movement was then very much alive and well. World War I was so horrific, with 40 million to 50 million people killed, that the world decided that never again would there be such a war. It was the war to end all wars. The Washington Treaty was set up. Australia sank its only battleship because it belonged to the Commonwealth of Nations and Britain had agreed in that Treaty to get rid of the most powerful weapons known to mankind at that stage. I went on to explain to Senator Georges-and I knew he was listening-that history proves that because Britain disarmed and was very weak over all those years there was no way she could negotiate with Hitler. Senator Georges is of much the same age group as I am. We saw Hitler move across Europe with no one to stop him because the Western world had disarmed according to the treaties. I pointed out to Senator Georges that there were not just national treaties but that people were in the peace movement. I pointed out to him that the Archbishop of Canterbury sought a peace prayer, to go and pray in Germany.

—On a point of order, Mr Chairman: I know there is a long bow that keeps getting stretched on these occasions, but Senator Walters's contribution seems to be reminiscent of her contribution to the second reading debate and not directed towards the amendments. Do you think you could draw her back?

—Order! The amendments before the Chair are the three amendments moved by Senator Sanders which deal with the prohibition of the exportation of uranium to France. Senator Walters has been responding to some remarks made by Senator Georges but she should now come back to the issue before the Chair, which is the prohibition of the export of uranium to France.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. Senator Gareth Evans would know that Senator Georges went very broad of the subject in debating this Bill.
—What did I do?

—I am not complaining. I am answering the points that Senator Georges made in that same debate. I pointed out to him that, when the crunch came because of the peace movement of the day and the countries themselves had disarmed, there was no way that Britain could withstand the onslaught of Germany. It was not until the Japanese went into Pearl Harbour and the United States of America joined our side that we started to wind back the aggression. We cannot have a peace movement that says: `We will have a nuclear free zone in the Pacific'. Senator Cooney said that that is a step in the right direction. It is not a step in the right direction to have a nuclear free zone in the Pacific. It does not mean that we will be excluded should there be a nuclear war. We know that everyone, worldwide, will be included in a nuclear war. The setting up of a notice stating `Nuclear free zone here' will not mean that the nuclear winter will not arrive. We know that we have to say to any aggressor: `There is no point in your trying to negotiate with us. We are strong enough to combat it'. We have had 40 years of peace. The most important thing is that we should have complete nuclear disarmament-not unilateral disarmament but bilateral disarmament. Both sides have to disarm together. I am sure that honourable senators opposite would agree--

—Order! Senator Walters, I said a few minutes ago that the subject before the Chair was the question of Senator Sanders's amendments to ban exports of uranium to France. I have allowed you to develop your general argument. You should now make your remarks relevant to the export of uranium to France.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. As you have said, this debate has ranged very widely but, as Senator Sanders has said, it has been valuable. I believe that honourable senators on both sides of the chamber have put their cases very well. As Senator Sir John Carrick said just a few minutes ago, refusing to export uranium to France will not mean that she will not have uranium. She will get it from other countries that do not have the safeguards that Australia has. As such, the Opposition will not be supporting these amendments.

—Order! Before I call the next speaker I again draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that the subject before the Chair is the three amendments moved by Senator Sanders dealing with prohibition of the exportation of uranium to France. After that matter has been disposed of, general remarks about the Treaty will be relevant. At the moment, the subject before the Chair is the three amendments moved by Senator Sanders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support what Senator Sir John Carrick has said with respect to the Opposition's attitude to disarmament and to refer to the terms of the amendments that have been very cunningly couched by the Australian Democrats in order to trap a few people in the Australian Labor Party who may, in their heart of hearts, agree with the text of the amendments. We in the Liberal and National parties believe that it would be impossible to prevent France from proceeding with an expanding nuclear program by preventing it from obtaining uranium from Australia. Senator Sir John Carrick pointed out very clearly that there are very stringent safeguards with respect to the use of Australian uranium by France and other countries to which we may choose to export that product in future. As the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) quite properly said earlier, the audit that has been carried out will definitely safeguard the use of our uranium for peaceful purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Georges's answer to the whole problem is that we should ban uranium mining altogether. That again is not the answer to the problem at all. Senator Sir John Carrick said earlier that we would support the cessation of nuclear testing not only in France but also with respect to the four other countries that have a nuclear capacity-Red China, Russia, Britain and the United States of America. We believe that they should all get together and reduce the testing of these weapons. However, Australia's failure to provide uranium to France will not help because, as Senator Sir John Carrick quite properly said, it would then be able to obtain uranium from other countries that are not signatories to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. France could obtain uranium which would be able to be used in any way that the French determined.

I believe that when the Australian Government ceased delivery of uranium to France some time ago as a demonstration against the tests at Mururoa Atoll it was a demonstration of concern but it was also a breach of a contract between France and Australia with respect to the provision of uranium for peaceful purposes. It was also in breach of the Non-Proliferation Treaty. If France had cared to take this matter before the international court I believe--

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have won.

—Undoubtedly, as Senator Townley has said, Australia would have lost that case because it was clearly in breach of the contract. I think the renewal of the provision of uranium to France that has been effected by the Government is quite correct. Another point that was made was in respect of the use of Australian uranium at Tricastin in France. Senator Townley and I visited that establishment when we were examining the nuclear fuel cycle industry a couple of years ago. During that time we also visited Germany and the United Kingdom. Inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency who are well versed in the question of safeguards and engineers and scientists are at the plant in Tricastin continually, so we know that our uranium is subject to very close scrutiny at that plant. It is interesting to observe that Tricastin enriches uranium for no fewer than 100 nuclear power stations not only in France but throughout Europe.
—But it doesn't do it to weapons grade, does it?

—No. This seems to be the emotive concern of the less informed members of the Senate, particularly the Australian Democrats, because they do not seem to realise that the isotopes from plutonium that result from nuclear power generation, the domestic use of uranium, are not the isotopes that are capable of use for nuclear weapons. Those isotopes are impure and would require expensive refinement to produce--
—What about the Phenix?

—The ex-United States expert says `What about the Phenix?'. I remind the honourable senator of what Senator Sir John Carrick said. He said that atomic weapons can be triggered off by plutonium that can be derived from sea water. I think that the Democrat argument is fallacious and nonsense.
—More expensive than sea water.
—It is quite true. The honourable senator does not know what he is talking about.
—How expensive will that be as compared with enriching reactor grade plutonium?

—It would be less costly. The other problem that was brought to bear on Senator Townley and me when we were in France was the pollution of the environment by hydrocarbon power generation. At that time the French were anxious to continue the program of nuclear power generation in order to offset the disastrous effects of acid rain. I note that in America, for example, 28 million tonnes a year of carbon dioxide is belched into the environment from conventional power stations. Nuclear power stations are with us. I believe that what we are doing is correct and I totally reject the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments moved by Senator Sanders are pertinent to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill, which establishes a South Pacific nuclear free zone. They seek to free a particular zone in the world from the use of nuclear weapons, the possession of nuclear weapons and the transportation of nuclear weapons. I must admit that I have serious reservations about the Bill in its entirety. Modifying this Bill with Senator Sanders's amendments would seem to me to bring some integrity to the exercise. A large number of nations in the South Pacific have expressed concern at the activity of France in this region. The reason the amendments specify France is that we are talking about the South Pacific region. We are talking about a power which possesses nuclear weapons and which still engages in testing those nuclear weapons in the South Pacific. This is the specific reason for singling out France. France is the relevant party in this Bill. By its exercises in this region it has shown that it does not care for the sensibilities and aspirations of the people of the South Pacific.

SPEECH.PARA: Not too long ago a conference was held in Parliament House, sponsored by a committee of parliamentarians. There were representatives from the United States, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the United Kingdom and France. It was made very clear that these countries between them possess the major stockpile of nuclear weapons in the world today-at least that is what we hope. From an answer to a question I put to the leader of the French delegation, it was fairly obvious that France's response is to pay no attention to the feelings, understandings and desires of the countries of the South Pacific region. That is why this amendment is couched in this way; that is why it is directed at France. It can be said to be a gesture but, in international terms, gestures are often very important. We are not necessarily talking about stopping the production of nuclear weapons in France; we are quite specifically talking about the attitude Australia has to France and to the French activities in this region. I remind honourable senators that Australia took France to the International Court of Justice over this very matter. It is a matter which still concerns the vast majority of people in Australia, Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu, New Zealand, Fiji and all the other South Pacific countries. The amendment has been moved specifically to look at that. Australia, as one of the main proponents and instigators of the Treaty, needs to take a very firm attitude on French activities in this region. Neither the Bill nor the amendment has been debated widely in the community, but as a number of people have pointed out it has been discussed in the Senate on innumerable occasions, including during debate on other Bills. It is a highly specific Bill and this is a highly specific amendment to it.

It is interesting that when these issues are debated unfortunately the debate generally tends to be one of personal invective. It is a pity that that should be so. I understand the feelings that people have on this matter. I have a very passionate concern about the problems of peace in the world. For this reason I support very strongly the creation of nuclear free zones, such as the South Pacific nuclear free zone. Ultimately our hope is that with the creation and linking up of enough of these zones around the world we will have a nuclear free world. We all know that we cannot achieve everything we wish to achieve in one stroke, but that does not mean that we ought not to do what can now be done. Even though it may be a small and seemingly insignificant step, the hope is that over time these steps will build. To restore integrity to this legislation, which lacks a decisive move towards the creation of a nuclear free zone, we believe that at the very least the Government should prevent the export of Australian uranium to France. This would be a gesture and a direct call to other countries in our region that we are willing to sacrifice economic gain for a particular end; that is, the solid and sure establishment of a nuclear free zone and the hope that other such zones around the world will be created by like-minded countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has been debating for some time amendments moved by Senator Sanders on behalf of the Australian Democrats to insert into the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill a provision which would prohibit the supply of Australian uranium to France until France ceases testing nuclear weapons in the South Pacific. Senator Sanders sought permission from the Senate earlier in the day to have this particular Bill debated cognately with the Customs Amendment (Prohibition of the Exportation of Uranium to France) Bill, which he introduced, which is to the same effect. It is true that the Opposition did not support that Bill being brought up for debate today. The reason I gave this morning is twofold. First, this is a Government measure. In fact, the two Bills we are debating at the moment are Government measures. At this stage of the session it is the usual practice for Government Business to take precedence over all private business. The Opposition has a lot of private business that it would like to debate at present. We see no reason why that idea should be breached to serve the purposes of Senator Sanders and the Australian Democrats on one of their hobby horses. That is why we did not support having that legislation debated. However, Senator Sanders is endeavouring to circumvent that by moving an amendment to the Treaty Bill to achieve the same purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has already voted against the second reading of the Bill. I do not want to go over this matter again, but as I have already said the Opposition is certainly not of the view that even if we are to have a treaty-we lost that vote as it was supported by the Democrats-the Democrats amendment will not improve it. As far as we are concerned, the Treaty would only be worse if the Democrat amendment were passed. Accordingly, we will oppose the amendment.

The Opposition's view has always been that Australian uranium should be mined and exported without the sorts of absurd restrictions that are placed upon it by the Government. The only restriction that we believe should be placed on the export of uranium is that it should be sold only to countries with which we have a special bilateral safeguards agreement to import uranium. Certainly, that should all happen in accordance with the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, with the rules laid down under the Treaty and under the International Atomic Energy Agency. Australia's safeguards agreements with countries importing our uranium are even more strict than the rules of the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Non-Proliferation Treaty.

It is not that the Opposition believes that there should be open slather on the export of uranium. When in government, we pioneered the strict safeguards policy. Within that strict safeguards policy we do not believe that France should be singled out and that there should be a ban on the export of uranium to France. It is another absurd restriction that was imposed by this Government when it came to power because it was giving in at that stage to its left wing over protest about French nuclear tests in the Pacific. The Opposition is strongly opposed and has been for many years in government as well as in opposition to the testing of weapons by France in the South Pacific. However, as Senator Sir John Carrick has already made perfectly clear in this debate, the testing of weapons in the South Pacific is not just a single problem. Nuclear weapons testing in any part of the world is a major problem and should be addressed on that basis and not by singling out France in the South Pacific.

That is not directly relevant to the point I wish to make. The Opposition has always believed that to try to use trade sanctions with France over this matter is totally misconceived. All that was achieved by the Government's ban on uranium sales to France was to relieve France from its obligations under a contract which was very beneficial to Queensland Mines Ltd and Australia as far as the price was concerned and enable the French electricity authority to buy that uranium at the much lower prices which now prevail. We do not know exactly what that contract price is because that has been kept in commercial confidentiality by the Government. The Opposition is not complaining about that although it is a bit unrealistic, particularly when one sees some documents that have been made available to my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Brown. Under the Freedom of Information Act he applied to the Department of Trade a few weeks ago and sought from the Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, all correspondence and other documents requesting appointments with the French authorities and Queensland Mines to discuss the proposal to remove the ban on exporting uranium to France. He requested notes of those discussions and all documents which showed when it was discovered that the ban on exports of uranium to France was not working. He requested information on the precise terms of any agreement reached and the estimates of likely savings as a result of lifting the ban.

Under this regime which believes so passionately in freedom of information Mr Brown got pretty short shrift under that application under the Act. He was told that the Department had identified 14 documents on the subject but only bits of two of them were to be made available to him because the release of the rest of them would be in breach of all sorts of exemptions under the FOI Act. That would be a nice subject for debate on another occasion. But again, I will not pursue it, even though Senator Gareth Evans tempts me to do so because he ought to learn about how his Government of which he is a senior member is dealing with freedom of information matters. I will leave that matter for another day. A couple of pages, an interesting little document, has been made available to Mr Brown. It is headed `Fact Sheets: QML'. We know that the Australian Public Service is incapable of referring to anything by name. It only uses acronyms so for the benefit of honourable senators and people listening QML means Queensland Mines Ltd which is the uranium company which was and is again supplying uranium to France.

Just to show how absurd is this exemption on confidentiality there are references to how many short tonnes of uranium have been supplied-or not supplied-to France. This document states that the Government has had to pay compensation and how much compensation it has paid. It gives the figures; so with an elementary knowledge of arithmetic it is easy to work out what the price was. It is around $30 a pound.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did it cost to compensate?

—It cost about $100m to compensate the company. The most interesting things in these documents are the views that have been expressed about the likely demand by France for Australian uranium. It is perfectly clear from the Department of Trade notes that there are very considerable prospects for Australia to sell uranium to France in the 1990s. I will read from the document that has been submitted to Mr Brown under the heading `Longer term market prospects in France'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Trade judges that good prospects for the sale of significant tonnages of Australian uranium to France still exists in the 1990s.

It is a pity that Senator Walsh is not here to hear this because he has been telling us that there are no prospects for more Australian uranium to be sold from existing mines. He obviously does not know any more about uranium marketing than he knows about the Income Tax Act. The paper goes on:
EdF-
Electricite de France, the French utility-

currently operates 44 nuclear power stations generating about 70 per cent of France's electricity. A further 18 stations are being built. After 1990 French annual demand for uranium will exceed 14,000 tonnes per annum.
EdF's long term purchasing policy does not exclude Australia-
despite the way we have been going on-

if supplies will be available, but contracts are already in place for the 1990s covering more than half of requirements. However there are indications that, subject to the early removal of supply barriers, opportunities exist for progressively increasing Australian tonnages up to perhaps 25 per cent of French requirements. Such a level of exports would return around . . . per annum in export revenue at the current floor price of . . .
That is what we get.

TALK.START.PARA: —Blank.

—The figures are blotted out, although another page indicates the price under existing contracts. In the 1990s it may or may not be the same as it is now. At all events, it is quite clear that there are very considerable prospects for Australia in selling uranium to France in the 1990s. If the contract price for 2,000 tonnes of uranium in the 1990s were anything like the present level-we will probably have to import large quantities of oil in the 1990s; it will be very important to increase our export earnings at that stage-it would be very beneficial to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the Government made the right decision in the end, having foolishly incurred high compensation costs of about $100m to Queensland Mines Ltd, which presumably it will now get back, having offended a very important buyer of Australian uranium and having made no difference whatever to French nuclear policy in the South Pacific. The ban was totally useless, and the Government has now realised that. The Opposition believes it was sensible for the Government to make the decision it did. There are now great prospects for Australia to supply uranium to France in the 1990s. We believe that the view of the Democrats is totally misguided, as is the view of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. We certainly do not support the amendments to the Bill moved by the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly about this matter.
—I should hope so because you have not heard anything of the rest of the debate.

—I might even say what Senator Gareth Evans was going to say, so I might save him a few words. The amendments moved by the Democrats are absolutely shallow nonsense. They are scaremongering and emotionalism. They typify the fear of the unknown. One thing that is not recognised as one of the greatest breakthroughs in scientific history in this century is the splitting of the atom. People do not agree with the splitting of the atom for nuclear bombs, but for some nations the harnessing of the split atom for energy for peaceful purposes has provided opportunities that would not exist without it. Let us talk about the real world. The percentage of electricity generated by nuclear power plants in France in 1985-I will talk about France because this debate has zeroed in on France-was 64.8 per cent.
—What about the real world? What about the rest of the world?

—I will come to that. In Belgium the figure was 59.8 per cent; in Taiwan, 59 per cent; in Switzerland, 39.8 per cent, and so it goes. As to the production of uranium, we have large resources of uranium, yet we are not by any means the largest producer. The largest producer of uranium in the Western world is Canada, which produces 31.2 per cent. One does not know what goes on behind the Iron Curtain. Australia produces only 10.2 per cent; Namibia, 10.2 per cent; South Africa, 13.2 per cent; and the United States, 12.5 per cent. At one time the Labor Government stopped the sale of uranium to France. What did it achieve? It achieved absolutely nothing. The Canadians applauded and thought: `That is great, we can supply the contracts that would have been supplied by Australia'. The Government, in its wisdom, has recognised the folly of its ways. We are not talking about testing nuclear bombs in the Pacific, we are talking about the generation of electricity from nuclear energy, nothing more nor less. The Democrats are trying to destabilise completely a growing world market for the production of uranium for nuclear power.
—I hope so. You've got it.

—It is all right for Senator Sanders. What if he were in a country starved of energy resources? For example, for the purpose of generating electricity, 3,000 tonnes of enriched uranium is equal to 30 million tonnes of coal. If I were in one of those countries, making sane and normal decisions, which I know are beyond Senator Sanders, I would choose the 3,000 tonnes of uranium. The Democrats, by emotionalism and fearmongering, are out to destabilise a top class market. What is the effect? That is easy to answer. Just go to another country. There is lots of uranium around the world. We do not have the sole rights to the production of uranium. If one reads the London Economist one will find that recently the Japanese decided to go to China for their uranium supplies because it is just a little too hard and a little too costly to get it out of Australia.
—Succeeded again.
—Senator Sanders has succeeded in destroying another Australian market at a time when our balance of payments situation is disastrous.
—You've got it.

—I am pleased to hear Senator Sanders say that we have got it. If he wants to destroy the economy, let him go right ahead and try. I hope that everyone out there has heard what he said. The Opposition opposes these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The freedom of information documents show a number of things. They show that the Government has misled the Parliament and the Australian people progressively over months and years. They show, for example, that information asked of the Government during the recent appropriation debates and Estimates Committee debates has been less than forthcoming. Australia has a chronically adverse balance of payments situation. That statement is not just a statistic. Because of the adverse balance of payments situation the people of Australia are being punished. They are suffering lower standards of living and carrying heavier burdens. It is vitally necessary that that balance be restored, and it can be restored by the development of an expanding uranium market.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party has a completely illogical uranium policy. It has two heads to it, like the god Janus. It must look to the left of the Labor Party with one head, saying: `We understand; we agree with you that there should be no uranium mining at all'. The other head looks out to the people of Australia, saying: `We know the facts. As good neighbours and under the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty, we ought to export uranium freely to the signatories and observers of the Treaty'. This decision is vital for the Government's Budget. The change from a policy of banning uranium to France to a policy of selling uranium to France is to balance the Budget.

During the last three years I have asked two Ministers for Resources and Energy, first Senator Walsh and then Senator Evans, why they would not seek the markets that exist for uranium. Senator Walsh's answer has now been proven totally wrong, as so many of his answers are. He said: `There are not the markets'. I said repeatedly: `Why not let commerce go out and find them?'. `No', he said, `the Government knows best'. Senator Walsh continued to say that while he was Minister for Resources and Energy; but the Australian Science and Technology Council said in its report to the Government that there were abundant markets and that there were hundreds of millions, even billions, of dollars to be gained if the Government supplied uranium as a good neighbour under strong safeguards. But no, a succession of Ministers said that there were no markets. In the recent debates on the Appropriation Bills I again asked about this because something called the little red book on energy has come out and it says that there are very substantial markets. I asked whether the Government would allow commerce to look for markets and whether it would ask the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia to again look at enrichment. But no, the Government knows best! The inference from Ministers has always been that, whatever else other people knew, the advice that the Government was getting from within the departments was that there were no markets. But here is advice from within the Government; here is documentary proof from the Department of Trade advising the Government that in fact there are very real markets-in France in this case. So it has not surveyed the rest of the world, where there must be many more markets. It is saying that by 1990 there will be an additional market for at least 2,000 short tonnes for France alone. That will do a significant amount to relieve the adverse balance of trade.

If the Government feels that it has to do a fiddle by selling uranium to France to fix its Budget, why not do the honest thing? After all, I repeat the fundamental that must be understood: Every nation, including Australia, that is a member of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty is pledged by signature to that Treaty to provide nuclear material for peacetime purposes to all other member nations. It is pledged and is responsible to provide it under the very strict safeguards. So Australia, as a signatory amongst 134 nations, is pledged to supply its uranium for peacetime purposes.

Australia has one of the large uranium resources. Yet although it is large, the amount we export is small compared with that from other countries. Clearly, Australia, under this Government, has missed the markets which we could have had, which could have produced literally billions of dollars more and which would have eased, if not overcome, the adverse balance of trade. The Government cannot argue that there is something wrong with doing this because, if it is right under the safeguards to export 3,000 or 4,000 tonnes of yellowcake a year, as I imagine it is doing today, it is just as right to export 5,000, 6,000 or 7,000 tonnes. There cannot be any diminished virtue or any diminished security in increasing the volume that is being exported. The only thing that can justify this is that the left wing has such a stranglehold over the Australian Labor Party that it is in a Janus, two-headed, situation and has to say to the left wing: `Keep quiet about what we are doing. We will satisfy you by saying that we will not allow any expansion of mining'. To show how illogical it was, it was saying `We will not expand mining at all other than at Ranger', but then it looked as though the South Australian Labor Government would be defeated in the election. So in a completely hypocritical decision, the Government said: `We will let Roxby Downs be a new mine because, of course, when they are looking for copper and other materials they will find uranium and it can then be exported'. There can be no logic in this. All it can show is that a series of people are standing over this Government to the very great detriment of the people of Australia. The vital need for Australia at this moment is to get our exports up and thereby increase our export earnings so that we can be more prosperous and employ more people. That is vital.

To show the absolutely ridiculous side of this, during the Appropriation debates I asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, who is in the chamber, about the proposal to develop the Coronation Hill mine in Arnhem Land. It is all right to develop the Coronation Hill mine in northern Arnhem Land but not other mines. Why? Because there are gold and other things there. The argument was: `We will get greater revenue for our export earnings to overcome the export deficit'. That is the thing: Develop a mine to get more money to overcome the deficit. But I said: `You are in the uranium province and Mount Brockman and its escarpment will, over a million years, have washed and leached uranium all over the place and you are bound to find some. When you do, will you allow its mining and its milling or will you dig a hole in the ground and put it back?' The answer was in fact that the Government would not allow its mining and milling but would dig a hole in the ground and put it back. The ludicrous nature of this must be seen. Here is an Australian community demanding more export earnings.

I repeat: We are not starting some policy de novo and saying: `Let us export uranium'. We are exporting 3,000 or 4,000 tonnes of uranium a year. That is the Government's policy. There can be no difference in expanding the policy, other than some snide bargain, made within the Caucus and made by the Government's trade union masters, that it will not go further. The Government stands naked. The emperor's robes are gone completely. The Government was standing behind one defence that Senator Walsh put up-that there were no extra markets. That was the defence when the ASTEC report came out stating that there were billions of dollars more to be earned and that, in the interests of safeguarding nuclear non-proliferation, Australia ought to export. ASTEC said: `If you want to make this world safe against the improper use of fissile materials, Australia should be a good neighbour provider to the world of these materials and monitor their use'. We had the best advice we could have, from the top scientific body in Australia, and we also had 134 nations all in agreement in a treaty enforcing that. And the Government said: `There are no more markets'. Senator Walsh said so. As always, he is limiting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I have not sought to interrupt Senator Sir John Carrick because I nurtured the fond hope that he might be drawing his remarks to a close, but his entire speech has been on general uranium marketing policy. It has not been addressed to the subject of these particular amendments, and I genuinely believe you ought to rule him out of order.
—There is no point of order.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I point out to you that the whole of my speech has been directed to a paper under the Freedom of Information Act--
—Senator Carrick, I have ruled that there is no point of order.

—The Minister is showing his disability. When one is weak on facts and weak on law, one pounds the blooming table. He knows that because that is the pleading of bad lawyers. He was pounding the blooming table trying to get a speech stopped because it was showing how naked he and his Government are. ASTEC says: Expand the nuclear cycle to safeguard Australia and the world. It says that there is a market. The Uranium Enrichment Group said that, with Urenco-Centec, we can get a market and have an enrichment group that will employ Australians in Australia in a chemical industry which will give Australia more export earnings and will create more jobs. But no, the Government would not do it; it banned further exports.

SPEECH.PARA: The other day the Minister said: `We may start it up again sometime'. How can we have policies that are non-policies? Senator Walsh says that there are no markets, the red book says that there are markets and then the Minister says that the Government knows best. I will tell honourable senators what the Government knows. It knows that its Department says that by the end of this decade the markets will have expanded by at least 2,000 short tonnes of yellowcake for France alone. What is there in the rest of the world? There is nothing left of the Minister's or the Government's argument. There is nothing now, except the left wing ideology which is preventing Australia and Australians from improving their balance of trade, getting more jobs and getting more export earnings. Incidentally, there was a lovely paragraph in that paper which says why we cannot get 13 or 14 of the papers. It is because it would breach commercial confidence in terms of trade. In other words, if they were available we would know more about what the trade would be. I can only say that nothing of the Government's uranium policy is left; it is totally in shreds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I will be very brief. I have always held the view that if this place were open 365 days a year, 24 hours a day, somebody would stand up and speak. I have heard so many repetitious speeches today that it has been awful. I will not belabour the point. Basically, Senator Sir John Carrick said that we ought to export more uranium and control it. That is about the same as saying that if we want to control drugs let us grow a lot of heroin and sell it all over the world and control it. It does not work that way. If uranium is mined and sent all over the world, it will be misused. There are no safe uses for uranium. We have seen that from Chernobyl, from Three Mile Island, and from Windscale, over and over again. There are no peaceful uses.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments have been scathed as being badly drafted, ill prepared, et cetera, but the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, said that they were an elegant solution to the problems which we faced in bringing them forward. Senator Jessop said they were cunning. This would destroy the argument on both sides, that this is some sort of shonky trick that we are putting up-ill thought out and ill considered. In fact, it is an honest attempt to put the Australian Labor Party policy on the shipment of uranium to France into the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill 1986. It would delay the Bill; I admit that. It would delay it for several months-until February or whenever the lower House would consider it. However, it would put some teeth into the Bill. It would make it worth while. It would make our friends in the Pacific sit up and take notice, and it would make the entire world sit up and take notice, that we have taken a strong step in the control of nuclear weapons in the Pacific.

As the operative wording is that `Australia will refuse to allow the supply of Australian uranium to France until France ceases testing nuclear weapons in the South Pacific region', which, of course, is Labor Party Policy, I say that it is time for those ALP senators who believe in the ideals of the Labor Party to show that they still have guts enough to support what they know is right.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sanders's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 16 September, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY AMENDMENT BILL 1986CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986MARITIME COLLEGE AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 November, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, the Australian National University Amendment Bill 1986, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill 1986 and the Maritime College Amendment Bill 1986 are all designed to give effect to one thing, to the decision of the Hawke Labor Government to end universal free tertiary education in Australia. That is what these Bills effect and that is what these Bills do. Each of them provides a framework for the imposition of a charge or a fee on most tertiary students. The initial level of that charge or fee will be $250. These are surprising Bills to come from a Labor government, and particularly surprising because it was Labor, and Labor's present Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), that argued so vehemently when in opposition against any form of tertiary fees.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember when we sought to introduce limited fees for second and higher degrees just a few years ago, in the 1981 Budget session. What did the Australian Labor Party say in relation to that proposal for fees when it was the Liberals who were proposing limited fees for higher and second degrees? Let us examine what Senator Susan Ryan said. We need go no further than Senator Ryan's own speech here in the Senate on 28 October 1981. I see the Minister smiling. I am sure she remembers it well. On that occasion she said:
The Federal Australian Labor Party is totally opposed to the decision by the Government-
the then Government-
to impose tertiary fees on students in tertiary institutions.
She went on to say:
We will be opposing generally and specifically, all such measures.

What a statement of hypocritical portent! How typical of Labor. When Labor was not responsible for the nation's affairs she said that Labor was totally opposed to a proposal to introduce fees. In government the Labor Party conveniently reversed and repudiated that position. Labor's opposition to fees was total and it was specific. Senator Ryan put it this way:
The Opposition-
that is, the Australian Labor Party-
is also opposing as strongly as it can this measure because it believes that it is in fact the thin edge of the wedge.
She said that our proposal was the thin edge of the wedge. She went on to say:
Tertiary Education Legislation
We, as I said, are opposed outright to those Bills . . . which seek to impose fees on students in tertiary institutions.
Senator Ryan was not alone in making those statements. Mr John Dawkins, speaking in another place, said:

It is not just that we are interested in opposing these fees for the groups of students who will have to pay them. We are opposed to the re-establishment of the principle of tertiary tuition fees in general.
He further said:
The Opposition-
the Labor Opposition-
is opposed to the re-introduction of tertiary tuition fees in any form.

So Labor pursued its total, simple, clear and unequivocal opposition to our fee proposal in 1981 and it pursued that opposition in both chambers of the Parliament. It sought to justify and underpin that opposition with the same arguments being used now by affronted educational groups who oppose the breathtaking audacity and cynicism of this latest broken promise.

Let us not forget that it was my Party that tried to introduce fees in a limited way for higher and secondary degrees and that it was Labor that then opposed them. It is now the Labor Party that, in an act of breathtaking audacity, has come in here and introduced what is in fact a fee for tertiary students. This is one of the most blatant of Labor's many broken promises in its 3 1/2 years in government. Those broken promises are alienating group after group. Because of broken promises students are being alienated from the Labor Party. Pensioners are being alienated, as are welfare beneficiaries.

Senator Walsh is trying to interject. He is a Minister who is prepared to be part of a government that, having identified poverty traps and having determined to introduce legislation to help ease the poverty traps, will not allow that legislation to take effect for 12 months and then when the time comes to honour that promise, 12 months later, puts it off another eight months. That is the kind of government this Government is. Welfare beneficiaries are browned-off with this Government, so are unionists, so are home seekers and so are wage earners. Labor, in the last State election in Queensland, managed to lose 2.5 per cent of the total vote it obtained in the last Federal election. That loss represented a loss of almost 7 per cent of its Queensland vote of about 40 per cent. I hope that the Labor Party will take appropriate note of that because it is disaffected groups who are sick of the broken promises who are turning against this Party. It will lose many more votes in a Federal election whenever one is held.

One particularly distressing feature of this whole exercise is the refusal of the Labor Government even to state honestly what it is proposing and what it is doing. It has already jacked up fees for all private overseas students. There is no question they are fees. It has already opened up the option of full fee paying places for extra private overseas students. That is a matter of record in the Minister's statement a year ago. The Government is now introducing a fee for most students, but in typical Hawke Labor Government newspeak it is not calling it a fee but is calling it something else. When it introduced its equal opportunity Bill it could not resist calling that Bill something else. The Bills we are considering now are about fees for tertiary education. If this legislation is passed a fee will be introduced. It requires many students, as a condition of their enrolment, to pay a new charge of $250 to the Government.
Mr Dawkins, speaking for Labor in more open, straightforward, honest days, reminded us as follows:
Another point that has to be made is that the Government is intent with this legislation-
that was our Government-
on re-establishing the principle of tertiary tuition fees. It is intent on re-establishing a fee collecting mechanism . . . That is why we-
this is Mr Dawkins speaking for the Labor Party-

are intent on opposing it . . . (If passed) it would be a quite simple matter for it in the future, without much fuss or bother, to extend the application of fees to include a vast array of other classes of students. That reason, if no other, is sufficient for us to oppose vigorously the reintroduction of fees. It is not just a question of the impact of fees on the admittedly relatively small group of students to whom they would apply; it is the question of preventing the re-establishment of a principle which this Government would have no hesitation in extending to include other groups.

That is what Mr John Dawkins said in 1981 in criticising our proposal, and it is what outraged students and student groups are saying today. But they are not saying it on this occasion to the Fraser Government, they are saying it to the Hawke Labor Government and to a Labor Minister. Labor still persists with the fiction that the charge is not a fee. Every student who has to pay will know that he or she is $250 poorer, whether it is a fee or a charge. To my simple mind it is a fee associated with their pursuit of higher education. Whatever the Minister may say, whatever kind of double talk she may use, the rest of the world has no doubt that this is a fee. The Federation of Australian University Staff Associations-the academics-in its briefing notes for the Federal Budget talked about it in the following terms:
In higher education, the Government has offset the cost of the promised extra places by levying a $250 fee-
`fee' is the word used by FAUSA-
on tertiary students. Although this is called an `administrative charge' it does not change the fact contrary to stated government policy the Government has, in fact, introduced tertiary fees.

That is the view of the University Staff Associations. We all know that this is a fee. Students know, academics know and many other educational lobby groups know. They all know. Not only is this a fee, but the charges will be unfair and inequitable in their application. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, representing all the vice-chancellors of Australia from the 19 universities, points out:

The Vice-Chancellors feel that it is inequitable that part-time students, including many that are enrolled externally, will be required to pay the same level of charge as a full-time student. This will mean that part-time students will be paying $2,000 and more for a course for which a full-time student might only be paying a little over $750. Part-time and external students are discriminated against by the flat rate charge. Further, many people are seeking to improve their economic status by completing tertiary studies and now, because of the charge, they may be unable or unwilling to undertake such studies.

Let us see whether Labor senators are honest enough to address just this one of the many inequities and inconsistencies. It is true that part-time students and external students will be unduly affected. I understand, although I have not seen them, that there may be amendments from the Australian Democrats which may put Labor senators to the test.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were circulated.

—I can tell Senator Macklin that we are the Party which openly sought to introduce fees in 1981. We are not going to support the Democrats proposed amendments, for reasons I will explain later, but it will be interesting to see whether the Labor Party is prepared to address the inequities and inconsistencies which the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee has thrown up.

SPEECH.PARA: No, the Labor Party sees this measure in terms of revenue. It is interested in putting this as a tax upon tertiary education to improve and to increase its revenue. It wants to do this to fund many wasteful, spendthrift and reckless policies in a whole range of areas which we all know are bankrupting Australia. This Government should be cutting expenditure in a large number of areas in which it has not. It should be bringing its Budget under control and it should be controlling the level of our overseas debt. No, Labor has introduced these fees to help replenish its coffers. If fees are to be charged they should be charged not just to raise revenue. The only justification for tertiary fees is if they will enable, allow and ensure greater access to tertiary education. They are permissible only if they will allow greater choice in tertiary education. They are permissible only if they can create a second entry stream such as the Government has allowed for certain private overseas students, who may be able to pay full fees. We see fees as being permissible only if they will give greater freedom in tertiary education and only if they will make tertiary education more responsive.

We want to see a system of tertiary education or higher education in Australia characterised by hope, expansion, excellence and flexibility. Any interest that we have in fees is only in pursuit of those goals. My colleague Mr Peter Shack, the honourable member for Tangney, made our approach clear when, as our shadow Minister, he spoke at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology on 14 August this year. This was about the time that Senator Ryan was quoted in the Australian of 9 August 1986 as having said:

The Federal Government has ruled out reintroducing tertiary fees in the Budget . . . The Federal Government quashed Budget speculation that fees could be reintroduced for university and college students.
Her Press release stated:

The Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, said at the Western Australian Institute of Technology on Thursday night: `We will not impose tuition fees'. A spokesman for Senator Ryan yesterday said her comments were `unqualified in their scope'.

What kind of double talk is this? They were absolutely ironclad assurances a few days before the Budget that there would be no fees and those assurances were unqualified in their scope. But what do we find? The fees come in but they are called something else to try to make them appear to be what they are not. The Minister can say as much as she wants that it is an administrative charge. I know that students will not be allowed to enrol, or in some cases to re-enrol, in a succeeding year unless the fee is paid. It is a fee associated with their obtaining a tertiary qualification; it is a tertiary fee.

My Party will renew higher education in Australia. We will release the energies of people waiting to be allowed to succeed and if fees for some people need to be part of such a system, we will lay out that possibility clearly well in advance of any action. Fees have been introduced by Labor in this Budget by stealth, by deceit, by pretending that there were no fees and by calling them something else. Honourable senators should ask any private overseas student in this country whether fees have been raised by large amounts. They have no doubt that fees have been increased by this Government. Full fee-paying places are a possibility under this Labor Government, but only for private overseas students, for non-Australians.

We now have the extension of fees to the majority of Australian tertiary students. We have to assume that the arguments put up by Labor senators and members in 1981 about the thin end of the wedge and about the increase in the level of fees are as valid today as they were then. It is likely that the fee-$250 this year-will increase. It will be used this year to pay administration costs. It will probably be at a higher level later because Senator Ryan has already said that it is to be indexed. So it will go up automatically each year to higher levels. It may be used to pay part of academic costs.

No doubt Senator Ryan, on behalf of the Government, is promoting this measure because she believes in it. No doubt she is introducing this administration charge or fee because she believes it is right for the country so to do. I want her to explain to us at some time what educational merit and justification lead her to take this approach on this fee in this manner. I am sure she would not come in here and introduce something in which she does not believe or something which she cannot promote as having some inherent educational purpose and goal. No doubt she will explain to us all in due course what that goal and what that purpose are.

When we look at this legislation we see another broken promise, another act of blatant hypocrisy and another betrayal of yet one more group whose votes were purchased falsely in 1982, 1983 and 1984 with promises which have been repudiated and which could not be kept. The $250 fee addresses none of the issues facing higher education today. None of the problems of purpose, mission, priorities and possibilities within higher education are addressed by this fee. Of course, the decision has infuriated Labor's traditional campus friends, and well it might. It is quite clear that, with this measure, universal free tertiary education in Australia is now dead. It is Senator Susan Ryan and a Labor government that have produced this situation.

As for our position, we regard this measure as part of Labor's Budget and, quite apart from anything else, we will not oppose it on those grounds. We say to the students of Australia that the way to resolve this situation is to get rid of the Government. But while the Government is in office and it introduces Budgets which impose such fees, Senator Walsh will get his 30 pieces of silver and he will continue to use it to bankrupt this country. The solution for students, pensioners and all of the aggrieved groups is for them to use their votes at the first possible occasion to get rid of this pathetic Government.

To Senator Macklin I indicate that we have some sympathy for the amendments to be moved on behalf of the Australian Democrats. We think that the logic of the position he is putting up is impeccable. But we are not prepared, in terms of a general view that we have taken, to interfere with the processes of the Labor Party's Budget and we will not be supporting any measure which interferes with that Budget process. We think that this Government is failed and bankrupt. But we think that while it is in office its Budget Bills should be passed. We regard this measure as one such Bill and, though we have nothing but contempt for the Government, the Bill will not be opposed by us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, the Australian National University Amendment Bill 1986, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill 1986 and the Maritime College Amendment Bill 1986.
