PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, paragraph 3 (c), paragraph (d) of the proposed new definition of `relevant enrolment', lines 37 and 38, leave out `by the Minister for the purposes of this paragraph by notice in writing published in the Gazette'', insert ``in the regulations as a class of persons for the purposes of this paragraph'.

I have a number of questions for the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) concerning this amendment. First, as the Bill stands the Minister would be able to exempt categories of people in receipt of Commonwealth benefits or allowances simply by notice in writing published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills notes that this may be considered to subject the exercise of legislative power insufficiently to parliamentary scrutiny. It says:

Notices specifying classes of persons to be excluded under paragraph (d) are not subject to tabling and disallowance as they would be, for example, if the Minister were required to specify the classes of people excluded in regulations.

Accordingly, the Australian Democrats move this amendment. Over the last few months it has become almost accepted that the Government will approve such amendments. Luckily, such provisions now appear less and less in the various Bills that come before us. This matter has been raised quite a number of times in the past by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and I believe it should be pushed fairly heavily in the Committee stage. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has been effective in tightening up the drafting of Bills. I hope that the Government is amenable to proceeding with this matter by regulation rather than by gazettal, the method chosen.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats' proposal is not acceptable to the Government as it would create absolute chaos. It seems to be the intention of the Democrats these days to make the business of the Parliament as chaotic as possible. We certainly do not accept this amendment. If there were to be a provision for disallowance the disallowance procedure could take up to 45 sitting days. That period could cover two or possibly three sessions and, of course, if the disallowance motion were successful it would result in different treatment for the same category of students in the same year; that is, some students would pay, some students would not pay and so on because of timing problems. The gazettal procedure provides certainty for students and institutions. The Government really does not find anything to recommend the Democrats' amendment and we will not accept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is unfortunate. The debate has been conducted in a reasonable way today. I do not know what the Minister had for dinner but I think it would be useful for this debate, which deals with an important issue, to be conducted in a reasonable way. The issue here is certainly one which governments of all persuasions have always relied on as being administratively difficult. We know that it is administratively difficult. That is the argument put forward by bureaucrats all the time; we all learnt that from viewing the program Yes Minister. The point is not whether it is administratively difficult but whether it is useful in terms of the legislative power of the Parliament actually to scrutinise such items. The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has pointed to this in innumerable pieces of legislation. As I have said, it has become less of a feature of drafting now and I believe that it is a feature which ought not to appear in pieces of legislation unless there is a specific reason why it needs to be done that way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has simply argued in terms of the time that a disallowance procedure might take. That is certainly true but it is also true of every amendment the Government has accepted to date. In my memory, in the last few weeks the Government has accepted this sort of amendment on three or four occasions. I cannot see why it is any more difficult in this instance. I would have thought that, in terms of this amendment, it is far less difficult. (Quorum formed) I was making the point that the length of time involved would have made acceptance of this amendment less difficult because of the problems the Minister had raised. After all, these charges are imposed once, at most twice, a year when fees are due. I would have thought that it was well within the capacity of the Government to make these types of decisions and have them put down at the appropriate time throughout the year. Unlike a lot of other Bills which work continuously, this legislation only works at highly specified times. I would have thought that the Government easily had the capacity, if we are looking at another exemption, to announce that at the appropriate time, bearing in mind the types of delays that the Minister thinks might arise as a result of any disallowance motion.

It is interesting that the Minister raised the question of the disallowance motion. If the items which are to be gazetted could very well attract a disallowance motion I would have thought that there was even more reason for it to be in regulations. By and large, I would have thought that it was basically uncontroversial in this area. We are raising the point that has been raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I must admit that the Minister's reply has got me thinking that there may, in fact, be other possibilities. At the moment I cannot think of any. I wonder whether the Minister will find that the arguments she has suggested are not really pertinent to the type of operation in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to ask a question of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan). Am I not correct, in reading the clause under consideration and reading the amendment, that sub-paragraph (d), to which the amendment refers, is part of an exempting clause which has the effect of relieving certain students of the duty of paying this particular charge? If that is the case, can the Minister tell us and, if it is, can Senator Macklin then tell us why it is necessary to have a disallowance power?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume is precisely right in his analysis of the effect of the amendment and its application. It applies to a part of the Bill which allows for exemptions. Therefore, if the disallowance motion rather than the regulation procedure were used it would be used only to disallow an exemption. That is, our Government may have decided to exempt, as we have done, supporting parents or invalid pensioners. The only practical outcome of the procedure that Senator Macklin is advocating is that the Senate could remove the exemption. So the student who enrolled believing that he had an exemption because he was an invalid, or for some other reason, would suddenly find that he did not have an exemption. This is why I made the point, which Senator Macklin did not seem to notice, that one of the main reasons for our rejecting this proposal is that it could create uncertainty among students and unequal treatment as between students whose exemption was maintained and students whose exemption was removed. I thank Senator Peter Baume for his accurate comment on the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to this clause, I wonder whether the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) could inform the Committee on the various beneficiaries. There has been a statement from the Minister about the various exclusions which the Government is proposing to gazette. I imagine that the Government has, at this late date in December, finalised its list. Is the Minister able to tell us, for example, with regard to items that come under the Department of Veterans' Affairs, whether the veterans' children's education scheme is to be exempt? That is the scheme for children of veterans who have died in wars or children of servicemen who are either blind or totally and permanently incapacitated. What effect will it have on a person in receipt of a service or disability pension, particularly as a service pension can be received by females at the age of 55? It may very well be that a person in that situation will still have dependent children. That person may wish to try to upgrade his or her qualifications in order to be able to support children at a later stage. I was wondering whether those two matters in particular had been dealt with.

—Student dependants of veteran pensioners or of blind pensioners, or other students in that category, will be in the same position as Austudy students. They will be recompensed. The treatment of disability pensioners who have had dual eligibility and who wish to undertake higher education studies is currently a matter for discussion between the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt). We do not yet have an outcome with regard to that category.

—I thank the Minister for that information. I was wondering when an outcome for that last category might be available. It is getting into December and decisions on tertiary study are often made much earlier than this. Can the Minister give an explanation, because I have not yet seen a full explanation, of why people on unemployment benefits specifically are being excluded? It seems to be very odd that in many cases persons might be excluded if unemployed but could very well be included if they become employed. I would have thought that the Government would be seeking in every way possible-I remember some recent announcements to this effect-to make sure that young people who are already disadvantaged by the economic circumstances are assisted. I am thinking in particular of people on unemployment benefits who are undertaking part time studies. A person on unemployment benefits has to be available for employment but could very well undertake part time studies. Yet that person might find this an extremely onerous burden, considering the low level of unemployment benefits, in terms of the costs a student who is undertaking even part time studies would be forced to bear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of Senator Macklin's question concerned when I can expect an outcome from the discussions between the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) on the treatment of disability pensioners. (Quorum formed) I was just explaining that we expect an outcome shortly on the discussions concerning disability pensioners. The other matter that was raised by Senator Macklin was the requirement for unemployed persons pursuing part time studies to pay the charge. That is the provision. I remind Senator Macklin that unemployed people have a number of options provided by the Government for them to undertake study and training to improve their employability.

SPEECH.PARA: Technical and further education courses, for example, all of which are vocationally oriented and in many cases specifically designed to meet labour market shortages, are available to unemployed people who wish to undertake that kind of training. It is not the case that the unemployed person who wishes to get some market skills has no option other than to undertake higher education. The vast majority undertake TAFE courses and receive allowances of various kinds-with a great deal of success, I must say. Most of those courses have improved the employability of unemployed persons. However, if an unemployed person chooses to enter higher education, while recognising his responsibility to be available on a daily basis to undertake employment, he is in a different position. However, we will be monitoring such unemployed persons carefully in the research project and should we find that the charge is a serious obstacle to the improvement of their employment skills we may reconsider its application to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendment to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 6, clause 4, proposed new sub-sections 4d (4) and (5), lines 9 to 22, leave out the sub-sections, insert the following new sub-sections:
`` `(4) The amount of charge for each relevant enrolment in respect of the year 1987 is-

(a) in the case of the enrolment of a person at a relevant institution to undertake a course, being a course which the Commission determines to be such as reasonably to require the attention of the person on a full-time basis-$250; or
(b) in any other case-$125.
`(5) The amount of charge for each relevant enrolment in respect of a year to which this section applies is-

(a) in the case of the enrolment of a person at a relevant institution to undertake a course, being a course which the Commission determines to be such as reasonably to require the attention of the person on a full-time basis-subject to paragraph (c), the amount ascertained by multiplying by the factor calculated under sub-section (6) in relation to that year-
(i) in a case to which sub-paragraph (ii) does not apply-$250; or

(ii) if, by virtue of another application of this section, an amount other than $250 was the amount of charge for each relevant enrolment to which this paragraph applies in respect of the preceding year-that other amount;
(b) in any other case-subject to paragraph (c), the amount ascertained by multiplying by the factor calculated under sub-section (6) in relation to that year-
(i) in a case to which sub-paragraph (ii) does not apply-$125; or

(ii) if, by virtue of another application of this section, an amount other than $125 was the amount of charge for each relevant enrolment to which this paragraph applies in respect of the preceding year-that other amount; or
(c) if an amount calculated under paragraph (a) or (b) includes a number of cents-the amount so calculated disregarding the cents.''.

The amendment is to page 6, clause 4, and seeks to insert new sub-sections 4d (4) and (5) to deal quite specifically with the application of the charge to part time and external students. The application of the same charge to part time and external students is inequitable. If the charge is to be imposed, it ought to be dealt with in the same way institutions currently deal with items such as the student charge; that is, there should be a halving of the fee for part time and external students. This is an administratively simple way of dealing with the issue. It does not necessarily solve all of the problems that arise but at least it would significantly alleviate them. Because of the average length of time a part time student takes to complete a course he would pay roughly the same administrative fee as a full time student. So the impost would work out to be equitable for students who for one reason or another carry out their study on a part time basis.

The Government has maintained that this is not the case because many part time students may-I acknowledge it-work or have an employed spouse. At no stage in the debate have I suggested-indeed I have not heard such suggestions-that that is relevant to what we are talking about. In terms of what the Minister was saying we are seeking equity in terms of the way students undertake their study courses. There is a whole range of reasons as to why people have to undertake their studies part time. They may do so because of family circumstances. Senator Powell raised the issue of single mothers who are seeking to upgrade their qualifications to be able to provide additional benefits for their families. In doing so they are already financially stretched. The imposition of a $250 administration fee on those people could easily be as onerous for them as it could be for full time students. Full time students are, on average, younger. Most of their recurrent costs are picked up by their parents. So exactly the same argument may apply to those on full time study as to those on part time study in terms of their access to other resources. But it is not a matter of their access to other resources; it is a matter of equity for the individual.

The total number of students in the bracket we are dealing with differs significantly from State to State and from region to region and is about 45 per cent of total student enrolment-a significant amount. It is a distinction which the institutions have sought to make on equity grounds. It is a distinction which the student unions, the sport unions and the various CAEs and universities have made in terms of the use of facilities.

The area of administrative costs is one that the Minister has relied on heavily, rejecting the notion that there is a fee. We have had responses from a number of institutions and they are in total agreement that the administration cost for a part time student is less than it is for a full time student. I believe the Minister has had access to similar types of proposals and information coming from, say, the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee. Indeed one could find under each of those headings a significant reason why one should seek to ameliorate this charge on those part time and external students, at least by reducing it to half, so that by the end of the full course of study they are paying roughly the same amount as full time students.

Most of the recent studies that have been done, including the most recent study, the review that I referred to previously into the efficiency and effectiveness of higher education, have pointed quite directly to the significantly lower socio-economic standing, on average, of students who are undertaking studies other than as full time students. Anybody who has been involved in tertiary education, be it as a student or as someone on the other side of the desk, knows full well that that is also the case on the ground, that many pressures force people out of being able to afford the cost of a full time course. As honourable senators know, the major costs to a student taking a full time course are his living expenses and not actually any of these additional fees.

The Minister mentioned in her response to the second reading debate that the Government is concerned about this, but I ask her: How concerned is the Government about this? Why can it not institute this now and see whether this is an equitable operation? Why follow the other course in terms of imposing the full amount when the Government is already aware of so many anomalies which will arise in this circumstance? Why not, in the introduction of this amount, seek to set it at the lower level so that those students will not be disadvantaged? If at a later stage the Minister finds that they are not disadvantaged, surely the amount could be raised. It seems to me to be odd that we should put on an impost then have an inquiry, find out that the impost is onerous and then lift it. I would have thought that the other way of working up to it might have been more equitable and more reasonable. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats' proposal is not acceptable to the Government. In the first instance, it would mean a loss of revenue of $20m and it would be a loss that we would be sustaining with no evidence for the points of view that Senator Macklin has put forward. I have already reminded honourable senators that the vast majority of part time and external students are in employment and earning wages, and that as yet we have no evidence that the requirement to pay $250 will present any real obstacle to them. It is also the case that the charge is regarded by us as a proportion of the administrative costs that an institution incurs in administering education services to students. Those services must be rendered every year for which the student is enrolled. If an external student takes nine years to complete his or her degree, that student has access to the administration of the institution for nine years-a longer period than a student who completes a degree in three or four years. There is an element of rational assessment in the provision as it stands.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin pointed out that in the view of institutions, generally speaking, the costs of administration for full time students is greater than those for part time students but, of course, the $250 bears no relationship to the full cost in any event. It is merely a contribution to a cost which would be greatly in excess of $250 for administration, be it for a part time or a full time student. As yet we have no evidence that the minority of students who are not in paid employment will find the $250 fee an obstacle or will not be able to borrow it from the loan funds. As I said, the research project that we are funding will look specifically at the effect on the participation of part time and external students, and the Government will examine the results of that at that stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the summary of the Minister for Education at the second reading stage she dismissed a particular group of people affected by this part time and external student impost. I think it is a dismissal that was made too lightly. It is not just to dismiss married women whose spouses are in employment. Studies relating to the family allowance have shown clearly that access to the family income is quite limited for a very large number of women in this category. At this point I suggest to the Minister that the review to which she has referred will be particularly important to this group of women. We should not assume-I am sure the Minister does not-that, because a spouse is in paid employment, these people necessarily have access to the funds which, in my view and, I expect, in the Minister's view, are properly the property of the whole family. It is not the case in reality. This is another group for which I am very concerned. If the amendment which the Australian Democrats have moved were to be passed, this would be another significant group of people which would benefit. In the event, it looks as though the best they can expect is the review to which the Minister has referred.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Macklin's amendment) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the assistance that will be provided to students, to which the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) made reference in her summing up at the second reading stage, I refer her in particular to the Press release she issued on 30 November headed `Commonwealth gives further $4.5m for needy students'. The first paragraph reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government is to provide a further $4.5 million to tertiary institutions for low interest loans and grants to students with financial difficulties, making a total of over $11 million for the period 1985-87.

That is a rather fascinating Press release in many ways. Senator Peter Baume referred back to 1981 in his speech. I would not want to go back quite that far, but certainly the Minister will remember a discussion she led in this chamber with regard to the removal of amounts of money from colleges and institutions. At that time the Minister said quite clearly that that amount of money would be transferred across to the emergency loans scheme in the triennium that was coming up. That was in the 1984 Budget. It was allocated in the 1985 and 1986 Budgets. The amount of money mentioned in the 1984 Budget was $10m, which on adjusted terms is now $11m. So there is certainly no further $4.5m. That amount of money had already been taken from the institutions and is now being put into the loans and grants as per that decision in the 1984 Budget.

I think it is somewhat misleading to talk about a further $4.5m, even given the propensity of people who write Press releases to use colourful phrases. Indeed, the media reported it directly, as presumably the person who wrote the Press release intended it-that is, that additional moneys had been provided over and above the amounts provided in the Budget. That is presumably what the person who wrote it was looking for. I think it is a pity that those types of misrepresentations are put about, particularly in this very important area. It makes it very difficult for institutions which are expecting additional moneys over and above the moneys previously allocated in the Budget. They are now looking at possibly another $4.5m being shared out.

I have had a number of calls about this and I have tried to explain what the circumstances are. I seek confirmation from the Minister that, indeed, that $4.5m is part of the $10m, now $11m, that the Minister had taken away from the colleges to re-allocate for emergency loans, as announced in the 1984 Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin is right and he is wrong at the same time. He is right in saying that there was a commitment in 1984 that over the triennium there would be a redistribution of funds which had been paid on a per capita non-means-tested basis to all institutions to make loans-(Quorum formed) The decision was made in 1984 to redistribute those funds to an emergency loans scheme, but the funds were phased out on a yearly basis for the triennium. So Senator Macklin is wrong in suggesting that no new funds are available to the institutions. In fact, $4 1/2m has just been formally allocated to them to bring the total amount over the triennial period to $11m. Nothing that I have ever said has suggested that there would be any more than a global figure of $11m for this purpose. But the extra $4.5m, or whatever it is, for the 1987 allocation has just been made available to the institutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister that in the Hansard of 8 October 1985 she is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: That scheme was inequitable and discriminatory.
She was referring to the colleges scheme. To continue:

We have changed it; we have redistributed the funds available under that scheme on a phased basis. Senator Teague will be interested to know that $10m has been allocated over the triennium for emergency loans schemes, which will operate on every higher education campus in Australia, which will operate under guidelines which require student participation...

The amount of money mentioned there is identical in adjusted terms. The Minister talked about a phasing out operation. Can she tell me what amount of money is going to the colleges on a phased out basis in the 1986 Budget?

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be no allocation in 1987. The $4.5m is being allocated in 1986. It is the completion of the triennial phasing out of one program into another program. It is a procedure which I have described and which Senator Macklin has just quoted.
—Am I correct in assuming from what the Minister has said that there is not an extra or further $4.5m? Is it the same $4.5m that has been referred to all the way along?

—I do not know how often I have to repeat myself. I have made it clear that a global amount of $11m has now gone to institutions during the course of the triennium. The final part of that $11m-the $4.5m-has just been paid to the institutions. Therefore, they have $4.5m that they did not have a couple of months ago. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to use the opportunity given to us by Senator Macklin's reference to emergency loans just to place on record some of the difficulties which some universities will face. I speak with a little diffidence. I am a member of the finance committee of a university and we have discussed in the last few weeks how we will try to cope with the matter of loans for students, whose numbers we do not know, who may have difficulty meeting this charge. If the charge is $250 and if we think we have $60,000 available, that gives us a total of 240 loans only which we can make for a body of several thousand newly enrolling, and maybe re-enrolling, students. If that money is to be available one year later-and the problem will recur annually-it is necessary that it be repaid during the year, so the rate of repayment will have to be relatively rapid.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to that, a university is not set up as a lending and collecting body, and it makes sense, therefore, to look at procedures such as going to the university credit union and working through it, as has been done, by the way, for the emergency loans up until now. It looks as if the university may then have to pay a fee to the credit union for each loan that is taken out. I ask the Minister whether she is aware of some of the very considerable administrative difficulties which universities will face in actually putting this in place, and, secondly, of the very real fear-it can only be a fear at this stage, because we do not really know-that the quantum of money available may not be adequate to meet the calls upon us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, I am aware of the kinds of concerns that Senator Peter Baume has just raised, because people involved with other institutions have raised them with me. But I think we must bear in mind that the institutions are getting to keep 10 per cent of every $250 that they levy, so they are considerably better off and that should assist them to meet administrative costs. Whether they are geared up to lend or not really varies very much. Many of the institutions did collect their own union dues and things of that kind, so they are geared up. Others used student unions to do that, so they are not geared up. So it is a variable picture. There are some administrative difficulties involved with this measure but, overall, we are talking about a charge which a large number of students will not be affected by and which many students will not have any difficulty meeting. The numbers who will have difficulty are quite small, and I believe that institutions will have the infrastructure to deal with them. I am not saying that there will not be any difficulties in sorting the matter out, but I believe that the resources are there.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment.
Adoption of Report
Motion (by Senator Ryan) proposed:
That the report of the Committee be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
``, and the provisions of the Bills be referred to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for report before 1 June 1987''.

It might not be necessary to go to a division on this, but our reasons for moving this amendment relate to what I said at the second reading stage: An inquiry into student finances and the operation of student charges has been long overdue. I move the amendment also in anticipation of reports that the Opposition supported such a reference. Senator Peter Baume may be able to enlighten me on that, because I am unaware of the Opposition's current attitude on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we do not support it.
—That is a pity, but due to the time factor we shall not insist on a division.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Ryan) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 11 November, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill is to cut off government assistance to first home buyers as from 31 December 1986 and thus save the Government about $150,000 this financial year. This is how the young, particularly the single income families, see assistance from this Government. I give notice that I shall be moving the amendment standing in my name, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add `, but the Senate condemns the Government for pursuing disastrous economic and taxation policies which have-
(a) created the current housing crisis;
(b) resulted in high levels of interest rates;
(c) reduced the number of dwelling commencements;
(d) reduced the availability, and increased the cost, of rental properties; and
(e) increased the public housing waiting lists'.

This government measure goes along with the highest home interest rates Australia has ever seen-rates that are artificially propped up by the Government to save itself from disgrace because of the true value of our dollar. Interest rates in Australia are some 10 per cent higher than in virtually every other developed nation, with rates at 17.5 per cent. Added to that we have rising inflation, the highest taxing government in the history of Australia and a falling standard of living. That is the scenario that the young people of Australia are facing as they move into housing.

So many of those are also in the net of the ridiculous fringe benefits tax, be it for a car, a phone, health cover or whatever. The truth is that people in the 25- to 40-year age group find themselves in real trouble if they are trying to raise children, participate in the community and buy an ordinary, modest home. I asked a question recently on mortgage arrears as notified to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. In answer to question on notice No. 1261 of 19 August, I was told that between January and June 1986 insured borrowers in arrears and notified by the lenders to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation rose by 70 per cent in the first six months of this year, from a total of 1,027 to 1,744. That is one of the results of the Government's housing policies. This time last year much was being said about the fact that new houses were being built at the rate of about 150,000 a year. Then the Indicative Planning Council forecast that the rate might drop to about 135,000 this year. Subsequently that forecast rate has come down to 130,000, then 122,000, and now it is about 115,000. I doubt very much whether it will reach even that level. The waiting lists for government housing have grown from 109,800 in December 1982 to 155,753 in 1986-that is a rise of 41.8 per cent-because of the number of people who can no longer afford even to contemplate buying a house of their own. As well, in my own State home loan repayments rose 36 per cent between June 1985 and June 1986, while wages rose 5.8 per cent. I ask honourable senators: Is this the Hawke-Keating housing policy in action? All I can say is yes, it is.

In March 1983 interest rates were 12 1/2 per cent and it is now impossible for the average home owner to get a housing loan at less than 17 1/2 per cent on an overall mortgage or a mixed mortgage. What is the Government going to do about it? That is what all these young people wish to know. Perhaps the Government will tell us tonight. Will interest rates go up or down? The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says they are going down; the Treasurer (Mr Keating) says they are not. In the Senate last week Senator Button agreed with both of them. How long will we be able to play this game of supporting the dollar and what will happen when the support ceases? How will government housing meet the needs of the people who are no longer able to buy their own houses? Does the Government really understand what its policies on the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and negative gearing have done to rental housing? Does it know what heights rents have reached as a result of there now being no vacancies in the private sector? Of all this Government's doctrinaire messes, its actions in the housing area must rank on top. I hope that as a result it gets its just desserts. All I ask is that when the next election comes, the Government at least asks the home owners of Australia to judge it on its record. I just hope that they do. The Opposition does not seek to delay this legislation as it is a tidy up measure. I move:
At the end of the motion, add `, but the Senate condemns the government for pursuing disastrous economic and taxation policies which have-
(a) created the current housing crisis;
(b) resulted in high levels of interest rates;
(c) reduced the number of dwelling commencements;
(d) reduced the availability, and increased the cost, of rental properties; and
(e) increased the public housing waiting lists'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill 1986 has several purposes, the main one being, as the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) said in his second reading speech, to finalise the receipt of applications under the previous Fraser Government's home deposit assistance scheme. That scheme applied only to homes purchased between March 1982 and the end of September 1983, so it is effectively a scheme which has no particular relevance to people these days. Indeed as the Minister indicated, again in his second reading speech, applications had dwindled to something like four a week and the administrative costs of maintaining a section of the Department of Housing and Construction to look at these was quite prohibitive. When the legislation was introduced the Government undertook to wind up the previous scheme and this is what this legislation does. People making applications under the old scheme were allowed a certain amount of time in which to complete those applications, but this Bill now provides that the last day of 1986 will be the last day on which an applicant can make a valid application under that scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no problem with that as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned. We certainly support the legislation, although I take exception to some of the comments that the Minister made in his second reading speech in another place. He lauded the current Administration for what it is alleged to have done in support of improved housing access, particularly for young people. This has clearly not been the case. This Government has not been much more generous than the previous Administration in making funding for public housing available to the States, in keeping the lid on interest rates or in encouraging people who are in a position to provide private rental to keep those rentals down. The Minister said that this piece of legislation:
. . . is one more indication of the priority we-
that is, the current Government-
give to housing generally.

That is in contrast to what has really been happening. For example, this year the current Administration has allowed interest rates for new loans to rise from 13.5 per cent to 15.5 per cent. The Government, with the co-operation of the present Opposition, has forced the private banks to keep existing loans at 12 per cent by buying them off to the tune of something like $125m. The Opposition amendment is not critical of the legislation that is before us but it raises a number of issues that the Opposition asserts are entirely the fault of the present Government. This debate is reminiscent of a debate we had earlier this year which was also led by Senator Archer in which he asserted similar sorts of things. He suggested that this Hawke Government and its economic and taxation policies have created the current housing crisis, resulted in high levels of interest rates, reduced the number of dwelling commencements, reduced the availability and increased the cost of rental properties and increased public housing waiting lists.

We challenged such charges back in October of this year when Senator Archer made them. We agree that there is certainly a housing crisis; I do not think anybody will disagree with that. Increasing numbers of people are finding it increasingly difficult to get the size loan they want at the sort of interest rate they are capable of paying on the sort of salary they receive, but such problems have not been caused simply by the current Administration; it is a continuing problem. It has not sprung up overnight. It has not even sprung up under the last two Labor governments. It existed during the previous Fraser regime. Possibly many of the problems have been inherited from that regime and this Government has not been able to solve them-that is assuming that this Government has any real commitment to solving the problems that exist in the housing area.

High interest rates are a problem that we all remember from the early 1980s under the Fraser Government when mortgagee sales occurred every day. As interest rates rocketed up, often at the rate of one percentage point a month, this put mortgage repayments well outside the capacity of most people on average weekly earnings. There were petitions, protest marches and meetings at which politicians spoke, organised by people in the so-called mortgage belt-certainly in South Australia-in the early 1980s in an attempt by people who were hard pressed by the constant increase in interest rates to make governments and politicians see some sort of reason. Unfortunately, such activities did not have a great deal of effect and the deregulated interest rate policy that seemed to operate under the Fraser Government continued to allow interest rates to get out of hand and forced many people out of their homes.

When that happens such people have to seek accommodation in the private rental market or they go on the ever-increasing waiting lists for public housing. Again, this Administration cannot be held responsible either for the cost of private rental accommodation or for the problems that are facing the public housing sector. It is not much better than the Fraser Government in providing funding for the States to allocate to public housing but it is marginally better. In the debate in October of this year the abolition of negative gearing, the impact of the capital gains tax and so on on the problem of housing in this country and such arguments as the Opposition is putting were well and truly canvassed and fairly well knocked on the head.

In November this year, the Australian newspaper raised the issue of problems with home loans after a survey had been conducted throughout Australia by the Real Estate Institute of Australia. That survey indicated that home loans have become more expensive throughout Australia since the Federal Government unveiled its housing assistance package in April. It pointed out then that that was a result of the partial deregulation of the housing loan interest market-a deregulation that was leaning heavily towards that which operated under the previous Fraser Government in the early 1980s. The industry spokesman who was quoted said:
. . . high interest rates were a key factor inhibiting housing activity.
I would have thought that that would have been obvious to almost anybody.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the average bear.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne, who probably knows, has just said, it would have been obvious to the average bear. According to another article on housing finance, the survey which was conducted jointly by the REIA and the mortgage insurer MGICA Ltd showed that the immediate effect of the partial deregulation on savings banks' home loan interest rates would be to increase the problems that faced people who wanted to borrow even reasonable amounts to buy or to build a home. The survey compared the increases in median weekly family incomes in the June quarter with increases in loan repayments for the same period. It pointed out that, in Victoria, the ratio of average home loan repayments to median weekly family income increased from a little over 20 per cent in the March quarter to a little over 27 per cent for the June quarter-a 7.1 per cent increase for Victorian families compared with increases in a number of other States which were considerably lower. The newspaper report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the increase in the size of average home loans indicates increased availability of funds to individual home borrowers. The trade-off, however, was costlier home loans with new home borrowers facing much higher average home loan repayments than in the March quarter of 1986.

I think it is about time this Government acknowledged that there is a crisis in home ownership and in rental in both the public and private sectors and looked at how other countries cope with this problem. I talked to a group of United Kingdom members of parliament who were in Australia a couple of weeks ago and I raised this matter with them. They were astounded to learn that for many years Australian governments have not allowed, as do the United States Government and the United Kingdom Government, a tax deduction for interest repayments on housing loans. Certainly this Government allows a tax reduction on loans borrowed for business purposes. Essentially, to all intents and purposes, money borrowed to improve a business is borrowed at half the nominal interest rate once the taxpayer subsidy has come into effect. If that applied, as it does in most other Western nations, to the interest payments made on money borrowed for housing loans, not only would we have a better rate of home ownership in this country than we currently have and more dreams of home ownership fulfilled-this is a country in which home ownership is rated very highly-but also we would have a healthier building industry, since this is a particularly labour intensive area, and the additional benefit would be increased employment. Therefore, the Australian Democrats do not support the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion, although we support this piece of legislation since it contains nothing to object to.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the notice of the Senate a matter which relates to an ongoing discrimination by the present Federal Government against a particular Australian family. During the Estimates committee hearings and the Appropriation Bills debate, I raised the matter of victimisation of Mr John Clunies-Ross, Sr, by a Minister of the Federal Government who, as part of a campaign to get Mr Clunies-Ross off the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, decreed that Clunies-Ross shipping companies were to be excluded from consideration for Government contracts to ship goods to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already outlined the clearly unjustified and discriminatory nature of these ministerial decisions which ultimately contributed to the decline and eventual bankruptcy of the shipping companies of Mr Clunies-Ross. But there is one further comment which I think should be added with regard to the answers that Senator Grimes gave to the questions I asked in the Appropriation debate. I asked what rights to redress Mr Clunies-Ross would have in regard to the ministerial decision to exclude his companies from the tender process. The Minister, speaking on behalf of the Government-perhaps he had little to do with it; if he had something to do with it the situation might have been different-stated that a person excluded from the tendering process can complain to the Ombudsman. That is interesting because I understand that Mr Clunies-Ross and representatives of his former shipping agent did indeed make representations to the Ombudsman regarding the decision to exclude Clunies-Ross companies from the tender process and was met with the response that the Ombudsman was unable to take the matter up as it was a ministerial rather than an administrative decision which was being questioned. Either the Minister or the Ombudsman is incorrect because Mr Clunies-Ross definitely received no assistance from the Ombudsman. As I say, it seems to be the situation that an Ombudsman is set up in the Australian scene to take up what is considered wrong on behalf of the individual, the little Australian, but apparently the Ombudsman has no power with regard to a decision made within the Ministry. It is quite apparent that the whole episode was part of a campaign to get the Clunies-Ross family off the islands. I am sad to say that this campaign against the family appears to be still going on very strongly today.

This same campaign was apparent in the attempts of the Federal Government to compulsorily acquire the Clunies-Ross family home on Home Island of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The Clunies-Ross family fought this action in the High Court of Australia. Thankfully, the Court found in favour of the family and refused to allow the Commonwealth to evict these people from their rightful property. It is just another example of how attempts have been made and continue to be made to remove the family from their home.

Another example came to my attention only this week. It is principally that matter which I wish to raise. When I visited the Cocos (Keeling) Islands earlier this year I had the pleasure of meeting Mr John Clunies-Ross, Jr, his wife Vicki-just a young couple-and their young family. They have a baby, born in August, only three months old, and two toddlers-one 18 months old and one three years old. The family lives near the old Clunies-Ross home on Home Island and is eking out a living by having guests stay on the island and taking them diving in the very clear waters off the islands. It is a tremendous place. I think that this family is fortunate that it can earn some income to enable it to live. The Clunies-Ross family is related to many of the Cocos Malay people on the islands. As I have said before, members of the Clunies-Ross family having married Cocos Malay people over a number of generations. Yet, in spite of the family's close ties with the island people, a situation has developed on the island whereby the Clunies-Ross family-I am talking about the junior family, the young family-is being treated as less than equal to other citizens.

It was brought to my attention yesterday as an example of victimisation that for about two weeks now the generator belonging to the Clunies-Ross family which supplies its home with electricity for lighting, refrigeration and pumping water from the well has been broken down. Members of the Clunies-Ross family have been denied access to the community electricity supply. While they have been loaned a small generator which is sufficient to supply power for some lights and refrigeration, they have to draw water by hand from their well. There is insufficient electricity for them to pump water from their well to provide water for the family. That has to be done by hand. This is causing great difficulties for the family. To many people it might be just a minor matter but to me this is part of a list of things that are being done to try to drive this family into the ground.

It seems quite incredible that the family is not provided with access to the community electricity source. After all, these people are citizens of that place, yet they are banned from getting electricity. They are Australian citizens with a legitimate entitlement to their property and their lease but they are the only people on the island who have to supply themselves with electricity. That is very difficult. My understanding is that they have sought approval for their property to be connected to the community electricity supply. The Cocos Malay Council sought the advice of the Administrator. The response was that it was not for her to decide. That could be interpreted in a couple of ways. The most generous interpretation would be to say that the Administration was acting impartially and declining to interfere in what should be a matter for determination by the local council. That is a generous interpretation because the reality on the Cocos Islands-the very small islands way out in the Indian Ocean that are Australia's responsibility and indeed now part of Australia-is that the Administration has a record of interference in the affairs of the islands, particularly where the Clunies-Ross family is involved.

My interpretation of the approach by the Cocos Malay Council to the Administrator is that because the people to a great extent are dependent upon the largesse of the Commonwealth, they have learnt that it is not in their best interests to put the Commonwealth or its public servants offside. Hence they have sought the approval of the Administration when approached by the Clunies-Ross family for assistance in a time of considerable difficulty and stress. On this occasion no advice was forthcoming but I am aware of at least one instance in the past in which advice was given. This was a disgraceful episode when one considers what the consequences of that advice might have been.

The instance to which I now refer occurred earlier this year. The Clunies-Ross boat, a small boat that runs between Home Island and West Island, got into difficulties off the coast. This could have been extremely dangerous in view of the nature of the waters in that area. I understand from a variety of sources that an order was made by the Administration on the islands that the islands' boat-the official boat which is quite powerful and can be used for sea rescue, Customs and so on--

TALK.START.PARA: —Zelman Cowen.

—That is correct. It was not to go to the aid of the Clunies-Ross vessel which was in distress. I repeat: A boat broke down in the Indian Ocean. The Administration said that the boat was not to go to the aid of the distressed Clunies-Ross boat. This could have been very serious. When one considers the possible gravity of the consequences, one wonders what level the vendetta conducted by the Federal Government and its officers against the Clunies-Ross family has reached. Is it now at the point where the safety and lives of the family are to be put at risk?

SPEECH.PARA: One could ask the same question about the present difficulties of the family, which I mentioned a little while ago, with its lack of electricity. That is perhaps a more mundane situation. I urge the Federal Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) to look into the situation immediately and ensure that proper recognition is given to just another Australian family, which has very little opportunity to stand up for itself, to see that those people are accorded their rights as citizens equal to other citizens on the Cocos Islands. It would be very regrettable if any member of this young family suffered unduly as a result of what appears to be a policy of victimisation against Australians whose only crime, it appears, is that they have inherited the name of Clunies-Ross.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Senate for very long but I feel disposed to object to an action taken by the Government recently. In an answer to what was obviously a dorothy dix question from Senator Childs on Friday last, Senator Gareth Evans, representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), informed the Senate and the people of Australia that an invitation had been extended to Mr Oliver Tambo to visit Australia during the seventy-fifth anniversary of the African National Congress in 1987. In the course of his answer I pointed out quite strongly that the ANC was a group of terrorists and had some sympathy with the South African Communist Party and that, therefore, I object to this invitation being extended to Oliver Tambo. I believe that the majority of Australians would support my point of view, not necessarily because of Mr Tambo's political convictions which, like the convictions of many members of the Australian Labor Party, seem somewhat blurred, but because he is the leader of a terrorist organisation and because he has actively encouraged the horrifying practice of murdering fellow blacks in South Africa by the necklace method.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators may be unaware of this diabolical method used to kill people. A tyre is placed over the shoulders of the victim and is then filled with petrol or diesel. Diesel, apparently, is preferred because it causes more pain. The burning fuel ignites the tyre, which rapidly attains a temperature of between 400 and 500 degrees centigrade. As the tyre burns, great clouds of smoke spiral upwards and short chain hydrocarbon fumes are emitted which, when inhaled by the victim, destroy the lining of the throat and lungs. The rubber also begins to melt and runs down the neck and torso, burning deep into the flesh and tissue. The victim is now a living corpse and takes 20 minutes or so to die. During this period the victim's family is forced to witness the cruel murder of the father or mother.

In the first four months of this year 250 people were murdered in this fashion by the ANC and its supporters, about the same number of people as were murdered in a similar fashion in the last three months of 1985. The crime of the victims is usually that they are law-abiding citizens whose only offence is opposition to communism and the ANC and displaying a willingness to co-operate with the Government in ensuring the peaceful evolution of change in South Africa.

I would like to consider briefly the composition of the ANC National Executive. The Chairman, as I have said, is Oliver Tambo. Tambo has been a communist but there is some doubt about his current professed political beliefs. From this distance I am not prepared to make any further judgments on that matter. His organisation is in coalition with, and largely dominated by, members of the South African Communist Party. The head of the military wing of the ANC is Joe Slovo, who is also the Chairman of the South African Communist Party. Honourable senators with a knowledge of the modern history of communist revolutionaries would be aware of their method of presenting as broad a front as possible to gain internal and external sympathy and support. Once a victory is achieved, the military wing takes over, imprisoning or executing its pre-victory allies. As an example I refer to the South Vietnamese National Front. Since the fall of Saigon I do not think anyone has heard of that group. Senator Jeremiah Denton, who is the Chairman of the United States Senate Sub-committee on Security and Terrorism, in his report of 1982 stated, in relation to penetration of the ANC and the South West African People's Organisation, SWAPO, by agents of Moscow:

I hasten to add that it is not my view that the entire membership of these organisations is communist. History demonstrates, however, that the original purpose of the ANC and SWAPO has been subverted and that the Soviets and their allies have achieved alarmingly effective control over them.

In 1985, and the situation has not changed much since then, of an ANC executive of 30, all but six were either members of the South African Communist Party or active supporters of that Party. I have shown the list of the National Executive Committee of the ANC to Senator Gietzelt, and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The list read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will note that the Secretary-General, the Treasurer, the Political Commissar of the Umkhonto we Sizwe, which is the military wing, and the Commander of that wing are all prominent communists, whereas, apart from the President, the Chief of the International Department and the ANC representative in Mozambique are just fellow travellers. The preponderance of communists on the executive lends weight to the evidence of Bartholomeu Hlapane, a member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, who stated before the Denton committee:

SPEECH.PARA: All policy making in the ANC was first discussed by the Central Committee of the Communist Party.

Apartheid is abominable and has had detrimental effects upon the social and economic development, as well as the political development, of the black people of South Africa. Its removal involves improving the lot of black Africans on a broad front. Politically, the South African Government has chosen to give all South African citizens full participation in local government. However, far from accepting this as a major step in the development of political participation for the black population, the ANC has declared war on all black people participating in local government. The actions taken are reminiscent of the actions of the Viet Cong against village chiefs and schoolteachers in South Vietnam, who were murdered in the most violent manner as a means of terrorising the countryside. Oliver Tambo made this clear when speaking over Radio Addis Ababa on 6 August 1985, when he said:

We have achieved a good deal of progress in making South Africa ungovernable . . . for months we have maintained an uninterrupted offensive against the puppet local government authorities in the black urban areas as well as other state personnel in the townships, such as the police and the agents.
Nelson Mandela also confirmed this policy as late as August 1985, when he said:
There is no alternative to taking up arms. There is no room for peaceful struggle . . .
Mandela, 20 years previously, had stated at his trial:

In our country, the struggles of the oppressed people are guided by the South African Communist Party and inspired by its policies. We Communist Party members are the most advanced revolutionaries in modern history and are the contemporary fighting and driving force in changing the society and the world . . . The people of South Africa, led by the South African Communist Party will destroy capitalist society and build in its place socialism. The transition from capitalism to socialism and the liberation of the working class . . . cannot be effected by slow changes or by reforms, as reactionaries and liberals often advise but by revolution. One therefore must be a revolutionary and not a reformist.

TALK.START.PARA: —A massacre.
—That is what it amounts to. Senator Kilgariff recognises that. Earlier this year I wrote to President Botha and urged him to release Mandela. I will quote the relevant paragraphs of my letter:

SPEECH.PARA: It is appreciated that the release of Nelson Mandela could cause some difficulties, as I feel personally that the ANC may jeopardise his safety for their own purposes.
However, I believe that if he could be released . . . this act would receive acclaim . . .

I believe too, that you should renew your willingness to negotiate with the ANC, as one of the black groups, but only on the condition that they publicly renounce violence, and ensure that their followers give it up . . .
President Botha, in his reply to me, wrote:

As far as Nelson Mandela is concerned I can only say that as soon as the ANC convince me that they are prepared to abandon violence as a means to achieve political ends, they will be welcome to have discussions with the South African Government. I have on many occasions stated this in public and at this stage I don't think it is appropriate for me to make any further concessions.

I believe that, confronted with someone of Mandela's intractability, our present Government would act in the same way as President Botha. Surely, a government has some responsibility to ensure that its citizens are protected from violence, reactionary methods of obtaining political fairness. I think it would be fair to say that we would be placed in a similar position. I know that President Botha would like to see Mandela out of prison. The South African Communist Party and the ANC, I believe, want him to remain in gaol. There are some indications that Mr Mandela would like to get out of goal, but I do not think he can afford to buck the Communist Party. There are many examples of what happens to those who do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like a necklace.

—That is right. People in South Africa are frightened to co-operate with the Government in any case-black people particularly-because they get the necklace treatment if they show any inclination to contribute to peaceful evolution of change in that country. The record of the ANC, in its association with the South African Communist Party, is well established. For the Hawke Government to talk about its opposition to terrorism on one hand and to invite the head of a terrorist organisation to this country as the guest of the taxpayers of Australia on the other hand is quite reprehensible and is another example of the double standards of the Hawke socialist Government. I object to this quite strongly. I believe that what I have recorded for the benefit of the Senate is a very valid reason why the Government should re-examine its invitation to the leader of this terrorist organisation to come to Australia next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to maintain before the Senate the issue of the alternative industrial relations policy being pursued by Peko-Wallsend Ltd and its supporters in the Liberal Party of Australia. Honourable senators will be aware that last month, as chairman of the Government industrial relations and employment committee, I wrote to the major shareholders of Peko-Wallsend Ltd. The major thrust of my letter was twofold. First, I sought support for a more co-operative approach to industrial relations and, secondly, I deplored the manner in which a Peko-Wallsend subsidiary closed the Besco Batteries works, giving only 30 minutes notice to its employees. I wrote because over a period Peko-Wallsend has shown itself to be a leader in taking an alternative confrontationist approach to industrial relations in this country. The principle underlying my letter was to point out to shareholders of that company that they have a responsibility to ensure that companies in which they have an investment practise a co-operative approach to industrial relations and that respect for employees should be the starting point for decisions in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: I now have in my possession a reply from the State Superannuation Board of New South Wales, signed by the President, Mr Bunbury. I will take a little of the Senate's time to read that very positive reply, the importance of which is emphasised by the fact that I understand it has something like $32m invested in companies associated with Peko-Wallsend. I do so in the hope that the message contained herein is heard loudly and clearly not only in the Peko-Wallsend board room but also in the board rooms of all those companies that feel impelled, through snobbery or political prejudice or other reasons, to treat employees as if they were disposable items akin to razor blades or table napkins. The letter reads:
Dear Senator Aulich,
I refer to your correspondence of 12th November, 1986, which you advise has been forwarded to the major shareholders of Peko Wallsend.

The Board is mindful of the serious adverse effects of poor industrial relations on a company's operations and profitability. A company's performance in that area has a direct bearing on profit potential and is entirely relevant to commercial assessment of a company in terms of investment opportunity. The issue is of importance not only in the area of corporate investment but also in property investment where, over recent years, the Board has, to an increasing degree, become involved in development projects.

In the Board's view, both company management and union executives have a fundamental obligation, on the one hand to shareholders, on the other to union members, and also to the community generally, to act responsibly and justly.

Instances can be readily cited of circumstances in which both company and union personnel have failed to address the merits/equity/commercial reality of a situation with serious and wide-ranging consequences.

As a substantial shareholder in a number of companies, the Board's officers are frequently in discussion with executives of those companies and, amongst other things, issues of industrial relations and industrial harmony are explored. The importance of good industrial relations is highlighted and management responsibility for sound industrial relations is stressed. These areas of discussion can be illustrated with instances where companies have improved industrial relations with, apparently, substantial contribution to profit arising therefrom. The example of the iron ore industry instanced in the appendix to your letter is, of course, a case in point.

Your correspondence states that it is the Committee's hope that major shareholders can influence moves to better industrial relations in the companies in which the significant investment is held. From the foregoing, it will be apparent that this Board is endeavouring to do so and sees its action in this area as being integrally related to sound investment practice.

In brief, this Board's position rates good industrial relations as of primary importance in assessing a company's potential and profitability. Poor industrial relations have ruined a number of companies; sound industrial relations have demonstrably enhanced performance and profits in other instances. The Board will continue to have regard to a company's record in that area in assessing it both as an investment opportunity and an investment risk.
Yours sincerely,
G. Bunbury
President

I also have in my possession a letter from Mr Charles Copeman, who is the Chief Executive of Peko-Wallsend. Since that correspondence has not been cleared by that company for general release, I will summarise it by saying that Mr Copeman's main complaints in his reply to me appear to revolve around the fact that my committee wrote to Peko-Wallsend's major shareholders rather than to him as Chief Executive. I will therefore read the committee's reply to Mr Copeman's complaint. The letter is from me as chairman of that committee to Mr Copeman as Chief Executive of Peko-Wallsend Ltd. It reads:
Dear Mr Copeman,
I am in receipt of your letter of 20th November.
The letter makes quite clear your objections to the fact that my committee has written to major shareholders in your company rather than to you directly as chief executive.
My committee did this for four reasons.

(a) Shareholders are entitled to know what industrial relations policies are being pursued by those companies in which they have investments. Already responses to this committee's letter indicate quite clearly that co-operation between management and employees is seen as an integral factor in running successful companies. I would assume that investment decisions made by shareholders would reflect that viewpoint.

(b) Your previous contacts with government representatives such as the Premier of NSW, Mr Unsworth and the Industry and Commerce Minister, Senator Button have not proved fruitful. In Senator Button's case your attempts to communicate with him were made only on the day that all employees at Besco were sacked. My committee does not see those attempts as indicating any real desire on your part to engage in genuine communication with either the state or federal governments.

(c) Your stated concern about the possibility of industrial sabotage at the Besco plant shows quite clearly your lack of trust in your employees. Your fears only serve to indicate how great the gulf is between you and your employees.

(d) Your desire for appropriate communication from the Federal Government is at odds with your actions in retrenching Besco workers with only thirty minutes real notice. My committee believes they were entitled to greater courtesy and consideration. We would be very concerned indeed if your company's actions should become the model for handling such matters.

Nevertheless, despite my committee's concern with your company's failure to maintain a proper industrial relations policy in the Besco matter we would be grateful for a more detailed explanation of your company's policy in this area.
I would assume that your influential position in the Liberal Party would not inhibit you from responding to our invitation.
I look forward to your reply.
Yours sincerely,
TERRY AULICH
Chairman
Federal Government's Caucus
Committee on Industrial
Relations and Employment

Because I think both letters are self-explanatory in the points they wish to make, I finish on the note that Australia needs co-operation, consultation and mutual respect in industrial relations. We cannot afford the luxury of this type of radical confrontationist politics impinging on the smooth and effective running of our companies. Both at Robe River and at the Besco plant, Peko-Wallsend is out of step with the express desires of the Australian community. Only a small minority believe that that radical hardline approach will actually work. I look forward to the time when the Liberal Party's flirtation with the Peko-Wallsend approach comes to an end and we can work together as Australians to get this country back on its feet again.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.01 p.m.
